          The <default> is returned if no evals are met.  The <default>
          is the assumed argument if only passed a single argument.
    2  -- Issue an allof().  Essentially returning every <eval> that is
          a true boolean.  This evaluates every argument.
    3  -- This is the reverse of '1'.  It returns the first <eval> that
          is a false boolean.  IT stops evaluation on first false <eval>.
          This again assumes <default> if no other arguments.
    4  -- This is the reverse of '2'.  It returns every false <eval>
          boolean. This evaluates every argument.
    5  -- Issue a strfirstof().  Essentially returns the first <eval> that
          is a non-null string.  This stops evaluation on first non-null
          <eval>.
    6  -- Issues a strallof().  Essentially returns every <eval> that is
          a non-null string.  This evaluates everyu argument.
    7  -- This is the reverse of '5'.  It essentially will either return
          a null or the default value.
    8  -- This is the reverse of '6'.  It essentially will return
          a list of nulls if you have such in your list.  This evaluates
          every argument.
  
  For PennMUSH function lineup:
      firstof(x,y)    == ofparse(1,x,y)
      allof(x,y,z)    == ofparse(2,x,y,z)
      strfirstof(x,y) == ofparse(5,x,y)
      strallof(x,y,z) == ofparse(6,x,y,z)
  
{ see 'help ofparse2' for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRCAT()
  Function: strcat(<string>[,<string2>,...,<stringx>])
  
  Returns the strings concatinated with no spaces between them.
  
  Example:
    > say strcat(this,is,a,test)
    You say "thisisatest"
    > say strcat(one,2,three,4)
    You say "one2three4"
  
  See Also: cat()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRDISTANCE()
  Function: strdistance(<string1>, <string2> [,<type> [,<damareu match>]])
  
  This function will calculate the levenshtein distance between two strings.
  This basically is the value calculated by the number of letters that differ
  between the two strings entered.  If either string fed to this function
  is null, it returns a -1.  You may specify the <type> of '1' to expressly
  require case insensitivity in the matching.  The default behavior is case
  sensitivity.  The optional forth argument enables damareu style matching
  which considers the transposing of characters a single difference istead of
  two.
  
  Examples:
    > say [strdistance(this,thiz)]
    You say "1"
    > say [strdistance(this,This)]
    You say "1"
    > say [strdistance(this,This,1)]
    You say "0"
    > say [strdistance(the,teh)]
    You say "2"
    > say [strdistance(the,teh,,1)]
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: comp()

  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STREQ()
  Function: streq(<string1>,<string2>)
  
  This function takes two strings and compares them.  If they match, it
  returns a '1', if not, it returns a '0'.  This is not case sensitive.
  
  Examples:
    > streq(this is a test,THIS is A TesT)
    You say "1"
    > streq(this is a test,this is a test?)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: comp(), ncomp(), match(), member()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STREVAL()
  Function: streval(<string>, <evaluation level> [,<arg>,<arg2>,...,<argN>])
  
  This function works similar to u() or eval() where it takes the <string>
  then evaluates it according to the permission of <evaluation level>.  You
  must be equal to or less than the bitlevel specified or it assumes your
  own level.  By default, none of the arguments passed will be evaluated.
  
  Evaluation Levels allowed:
      CIT[IZEN]     -- Mortal (bit level 1)
      GUILD[MASTER] -- Staff (bit level 2)
      ARCH[ITECT]   -- Staff (bit level 3)
      COUN[CILOR]   -- Staff (bit level 4)
      ROY[ALTY]     -- Staff (bit level 5) -- This is a full Wizard
      IMM[ORTAL]    -- Staff (bit level 6) -- This is essentially #1
      GOD           -- Staff (bit level 7) -- Can only be ran as #1
  
  Examples: (assuming your a full wizard (royalty))
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],immortal)
    You say "5"                  (immortal is above your lvl, so ignores)
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],councilor)
    You say "4"
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)] -- Arg %0,citizen,foo!)]
    You say "1 -- Arg foo!"
    > say streval(NoEval: %0 ... Eval: [s(%0)],citizen,[add(1,1)])
    You say "Noeval: [add(1,1)] ... Eval: 2"
    > say streval(Test: [s(%0)],citizen,[bittype(me)])
    You say "Test: 1"
  
  See Also: ueval(), u(), default(), subeval(), sandbox(), objeval(), 
            @lfunction
    


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRFIRSTOF()
  Function: ofparse(<type>, [<eval1> [,<eval2> ... <evalN or delim>]])

  Type 1&3: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>)
  Type 2&4: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>)
  Type 5&7: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>)
  Type 6&8: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>)
  
  This function will take each <eval> and returns it based on the <type>.
  
  The following types exist:
    1  -- Issue a firstof().  Essentially return the first <eval> that is
          a true boolean.  This stops evaluation on first true <eval>.
          The <default> is returned if no evals are met.  The <default>
          is the assumed argument if only passed a single argument.
    2  -- Issue an allof().  Essentially returning every <eval> that is
          a true boolean.  This evaluates every argument.
    3  -- This is the reverse of '1'.  It returns the first <eval> that
          is a false boolean.  IT stops evaluation on first false <eval>.
          This again assumes <default> if no other arguments.
    4  -- This is the reverse of '2'.  It returns every false <eval>
          boolean. This evaluates every argument.
    5  -- Issue a strfirstof().  Essentially returns the first <eval> that
          is a non-null string.  This stops evaluation on first non-null
          <eval>.
    6  -- Issues a strallof().  Essentially returns every <eval> that is
          a non-null string.  This evaluates everyu argument.
    7  -- This is the reverse of '5'.  It essentially will either return
          a null or the default value.
    8  -- This is the reverse of '6'.  It essentially will return
          a list of nulls if you have such in your list.  This evaluates
          every argument.
  
  For PennMUSH function lineup:
      firstof(x,y)    == ofparse(1,x,y)
      allof(x,y,z)    == ofparse(2,x,y,z)
      strfirstof(x,y) == ofparse(5,x,y)
      strallof(x,y,z) == ofparse(6,x,y,z)
  
{ see 'help ofparse2' for examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRFUNC()
  Function: strfunc(<function>, <list of arguments>[,<delim>])
  
  The strfunc (string function) function is used to transform a 
  string of arguments into separate identified arguments and feed 
  them into the specified function.  If you do not have access to the 
  function or if you give the target function an invalid number of 
  arguments, an error message will be displayed.
  
  This in effect will turn any function in the game into a string
  oriented function.  Thus the name, 'strfunc'.
  
  Examples:
    > say add(1,2,3,4)
    You say "10"
    > say strfunc(add,1 2 3 4)
    You say "10"
    > say strfunc(add,1@2@3@4,@)
    You say "10"
    > say hastype(me,player)
    You say "1"
    > say strfunc(hastype,me player)
    You say "1"
    > say switch(add(1,1),2,match,1,nope,0,nope,nope)
    You say "match"
    > say strfunc(switch,add(1,1) 2 match 1 nope 0 nope nope)
    You say "match"
  
  See Also: strmath(), ladd(), lsub(), ldiv(), lmul()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



string functions
  Function Lists: String Functions
     
  accent()      - Apply high order bit accent/umlaut/etc on strings.
  after()       - Returns the contents of a string after the specified word.
  andchr()      - Returns 1 if specified string contains specified characters.
  before()      - Returns the contents of a string before the specified word.
  brackets()    - Returns a count of left and right (,{ and [ in a string
  capstr()      - Capitalizes a string.
  case()        - Case is like switch(), but does not do wildcard matching.
  caseall()     - Like case(), but will match all cases not just the first.
  cat()         - Concaternates two strings together.
  center()      - Centers text on a specified width.
  chomp()       - Strips carriage returns from start, end or both of a string.
  columns()     - Powerful column formatting tool.
  comp()        - Compares two strings. 
  creplace()    - Like replace(), but works on characters instead of words.
  decode64()    - Decode a 64 compressed string.
  decrypt()     - Decrypt a string based on an offset.
  delete()      - Deletes characters from a string.
  edit()        - Edits a string, replacing, prepending or appending text.
  editansi()    - Edits the ansi encoding of a string.
  elementpos()  - Return the character(s) specified by the positions.
  encode64()    - Encode a string to compressed 64.
  encrypt()     - Encrypt a string based on an offset.
  escape()      - Adds escape characters to some special characters.
  escapex()     - Like escape() but allows specifying characters not to escape.
  esclist()     - Escape optionally specified characters from a string.
  eval()        - Evaluates code.
  garble()      - Garbles input by replacing text.
  ifelse()      - Returns true if an expression evaluates as true.
  isalnum()     - Returns true if first character of input is alphanumeric.
  isalpha()     - Returns true if first character of input is an alpha char.
  isdbref()     - Returns true if passed a valid dbref.
  isdigit()     - Returns true if first character of input is a digit.
  
  { Continued in string functions2 }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



string functions2
  Continued from String Functions.
      
  isnum()       - Returns true if input is a number.
  isobjid()     - Returns true if input is an objid.
  ispunct()     - Returns true if first character of input is a punctuation.
  isspace()     - Returns true if first character of input is a whitespace.
  istag()       - Returns true if passed a valid tag.
  isword()      - Returns true if the argument contains only alpha characters. 
  isxdigit()    - Returns true if first character of input is a hexadecimal.
  lcstr()       - Lowercases a string.
  left()        - Extracts X characters from a string, starting from the left.
  lit()         - Returns a string as-is, without formatting or evaluation.
  ljc()         - Left justifies and cuts a string to a specified width.
  ljust()       - Pads a string with trailing fill characters.
  merge()       - Merges two strings together.
  mid()         - Extracts X characters from a string, from anywhere inside it.
  mwords()      - Returns the number of words in a string (with multi-delim).
  nostr()       - The exact opposite of str().
  notchr()      - Returns true if NONE of the specified chars are in string.
  numpos()      - Returns the total number of matches of a character in string.
  ofparse()     - Returns various manipulations of evaluated strings.
  orchr()       - Returns true if any of the specified chars are in a string.
  parsestr()    - Parses a string according to formatting rules.
  pedit()       - Like edit(), but with PennMUSH functionality.
  pos()         - Returns the position of where a substring begins in a string.
  printf()      - Formats text left, center, right, or stretched justification.
  randpos()     - Like totpos(), but totally randomizes output.
  repeat()      - Repeats input X times.
  replace()     - Replaces a word in a list at a specified position.
  right()       - Extracts X characters from a string, starting from the right.
  rjc()         - Right justifies and cuts a string to a specified width.
  rjust()       - Right justifies a string by padding it with specified char.
  rotl()        - Rotates a string X characters to the left.
  rotr()        - Rotates a string X characters to the right.
  s()           - Force evaluation of a string.
  
  { Continued in string functions3 }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



string functions3
  Continued from string functions2
    
  sandbox()     - Evaluates code with specific function restrictions
  scramble()    - Scrambles a string, returning the characters randomly.
  secure()      - Removes special characters from a string.
  securex()     - Like secure(), but you can specify characters not to remove.
  shl()         - Performs a leftwards bitshift on a number.
  shr()         - Performs a rightwards bitshift on a number.
  shuffle()     - Shuffles the words of a string.
  space()       - Returns X number of whitespace.
  splice()      - Splices two lists together.
  squish()      - Removes excess spaces or delimiters from a string.
  stderr()      - Convert all #-1 errors to notify() and not the stack.
  str()         - Like after(), and similar to C strstr().
  strdistance() - Calculates the levenshtein distance between two strings.
  streq()       - Compares two strings, returning true if they match.
  streval()     - Evaluates the string based on the permission level specified.
  strip()       - Strips out every occurrence of a character in a string.
  stripaccents()- Strip accents from specified string.
  strlen()      - Returns the length of a string.
  strlenraw()   - Returns the length of the RAW string.
  strlenvis()   - Returns the length of the VISUAL string.
  strmatch()    - Returns true if a pattern is found in a string.
  subeval()     - Performs pronoun substitution on a string.
  subnetmatch() - Returns true if an IP address is part of a subnet.
  switch()      - Powerful string-pattern conditional.
  switchall()   - Like switch(), but matches all occurrences of a pattern.
  t()           - Unifies MUSH responses of 0, null or #-* to return 0.
  template()    - Direct WYSIWYG substitution in a template string.
  totpos()      - Returns all the positions of a match in a string.
  tr()          - Transforms a string based on find and replace lists.
  translate()   - Translates special characters to percent substitutions.
  trim()        - Trims trailing and leading spaces from a string.
  ucstr()       - Upper-cases a string.
  unesclist()   - Escape optionally specified characters from a string.
  wordpos()     - Returns the position of a word in a string.
  words()       - Returns the number of words in a string.
  wrap()        - Formats a string by wrapping it, much like columns()
  wrapcolumns() - Like wrap() and columns(). See help for more.
  xorchr()      - Returns true if only ONE occurrence of a character is found.




[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRIP()
  Function: strip(<string1>,<string2> [,<type>])
  
  This function strips out every occurance of every character of <string2>
  from <string1> and returns <string1>.  The strip function is case
  sensitive.
  
  If <type> is specified as '1', then the functionality is reversed and
  it will only keep all characters in <string1> that exist in <string2>.
  
  Examples:
    > say strip(This is a test,is)
    You say "Th  a tet"
    > say strip(abcdefgABCDEFG,azGy!7$B)
    You say "bcdefgACDEF"
    > say strip(This is a test,is,1)
    You say "isiss"
  
  See Also: @edit, edit(), editansi(), garble(), chomp(), regedit(),
            elementpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRIPACCENTS()
  Function: stripaccents(<string>)
  
  Returns the string with accented characters converted to non-accented.
  This function assumes the ISO 8859-1 character set.
  
  Example:
    > say stripaccents(Aul(e-with-diaeresis))
    You say "Aule"
   
  See Also: chr(), asc(), strip(), stripansi(), tr(), accent(), ACCENTS.

  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRIPANSI()
  Function: stripansi(<string>)
  
  Returns the string with all ansi codes removed.
  
  Example:
    > say stripansi(ansi(hr,red))
    You say "red"
  
  See Also: NO_FLASH, ANSI, ANSICOLOR, stripaccents(), ansipos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRLEN()
  Function: strlen(<string>)
            strlenvis(<string>)
            strlenraw(<string>)
 
  Returns the number of characters in <string>.
 
  Example:
    > say strlen(This is a test)
    You say "14"
    > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea)
    You say "37"
  
  The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of
  the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each).
  This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values.
  
  The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including
  any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi.  This
  is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string
  for length checks or the like.
    
  See Also: words(), wordpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRLENRAW()
  Function: strlen(<string>)
            strlenvis(<string>)
            strlenraw(<string>)
 
  Returns the number of characters in <string>.
 
  Example:
    > say strlen(This is a test)
    You say "14"
    > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea)
    You say "37"
  
  The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of
  the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each).
  This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values.
  
  The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including
  any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi.  This
  is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string
  for length checks or the like.
    
  See Also: words(), wordpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRLENVIS()
  Function: strlen(<string>)
            strlenvis(<string>)
            strlenraw(<string>)
 
  Returns the number of characters in <string>.
 
  Example:
    > say strlen(This is a test)
    You say "14"
    > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea)
    You say "37"
  
  The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of
  the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each).
  This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values.
  
  The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including
  any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi.  This
  is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string
  for length checks or the like.
    
  See Also: words(), wordpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRMATCH()
  Function: strmatch(<string>,<pattern>)
 
  This function matches <pattern> against the entire <string>, returning 1
  if it matches and 0 if it does not.  The case of the characters being
  matched is not significant.
 
  The pattern may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' matches any one
  character, while '*' matches any number of characters, including none.
  So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', but 's*x' would
  match any of them.
 
  Examples:
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*Test)
    You say "1"
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*This)
    You say "0"
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*is*is*)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: match(), member(), nummatch(), nummember(), totmatch(), totmember()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



strmath()
  Function: strmath (syntax follows)
  strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>)
  
  The strmath function is used to apply math to the entire string.  Numbers
  in the string are modified based on the math chosen applied to the number.
  You may specify optional input and output separators.  You may also specify
  the word to start (<st>) the math on and how many words (<amt>) after the 
  start you wish to use. If no math is specified, '+' is used as a default.
  The <idlm> and <isep> are inner delimiter and separator to use for the 
  normal delimited string.  This is so you can separate values such as:
  
                    To hit:5|To Damage:10|Base AC:15
  
  Note:  It handles floating point notation, so values with decimals are seen.
   
    Key:  str  -- input string    num  -- value to apply  math -- math to use
          dlm  -- delimiter       sep  -- separator       st   -- start value
          amt  -- word count      idlm -- inner delim     isep -- inner sep
          low  -- low val match   hi   -- high val match
  
  You may specify the 'low' and 'hi' values to specify a range of what values
  you wish to apply the math to.
   
{ see 'help strmath2' for value values for <math> and examples }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



strmath2
  Function: strmath (syntax follows)  (CONTINUED)
  strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>)
  
  Valid <math> arguments are:
        + - apply addition to all numbers in the string.
        - - apply subtraction to all numbers in the string.
        / - apply division to all numbers in the string.
        * - apply multiplication to all numbers in the string.
       %% - return remainder of division. (you need to use two %%'s)
  
  Valid conditional <math> arguments are:
         <VALUE - set to <num> for every condition < VALUE (eg. <10)
         >VALUE - set to <num> for every condition > VALUE (eg. >10)
         =VALUE - set to <num> for every condition = VALUE (eg. =10)
        !=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition != VALUE (eg. !=10)
        <=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition <= VALUE (eg. <=10)
        >=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition >= VALUE (eg. >=10)
  
  Examples:
    > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish green fish blue fish,10,+)   (default)
    You say "11 fish 12 fish green fish blue fish"
    > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish green fish blue fish,10,*)
    You say "10 fish 20 fish green fish blue fish"
    > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish 3 shoe 4 shoe,10,+,,,3,2)
    You say "1 fish 12 fish 13 shoe 4 shoe"
    > say strmath(To hit:5|To Damage:10|Base AC:15,150,+,|,|,1,0,:,:)
    You say "To hit:155|To Damage:10|Base AC:15"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,<40)
    You say "0 beats 0 but is less than 100"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,>40)
    You say "10 beats 5 but is less than 0"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,=5)
    You say "10 beats 0 but is less than 100"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,!=5)
    You say "0 beats 5 but is less than 0"
  
  See Also: add(), sub(), mul(), div(), mod(), strfunc(), spellnum()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



STRTRUNC()
  Function: left(<string>, <position> [,<key>])
   (Alias): strtrunc(<string>,<position> [,<key>])
  
  Left will take a string and return the left-most position of characters
  from the string.
  
  You may specify a <key> of 1 to tell left() to take the string raw and
  not do ansi-aware processing.  This will speed up the function.
  The default is '0' which does ansi processing.
  
  Note: the config param 'ansi_default' handles if the ansi handling is 
        configured default or not.  In which case the 'key' is reversed.
   
  Example:
    > say left(this is a test,5)
    You say "this "
    > say left(this is a test,10000)
    You say "this is a test"
    > say left(this is a test,0)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: right(), mid(), delete(), ljc(), rjc()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SUB()
  Function: sub(<number1>,<number2>[,<numberN>]...)
   
  Returns the result of subtracting <number2> from <number1>.
  The numbers may be floating point numbers, and a floating point result
  is returned.  
   
  Numbers may be floating point numbers, and a floating point result
  is returned.
   
  Example:
    > say sub(5,2)
    You say "3"
  
  See Also: add(), div(), mod(), mul()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SUBEVAL()
  Function: subeval(<string> [,,<key>])
            subeval(<thing>, <attribute> [,<key>])
  
  This function will evaluate <string> by parsing all substitutions but will 
  not evaluate functions, built in or otherwise.
  
  The second form will evaluate <attribute> from <thing> parsing all
  substitutions but not evaluating any functions, built in or otherwise.
  
  You must be able to control <thing> to fetch the attribute.
  
  You may specify an optional <key> in both forms of 1 to force a double-parse
  of substitutions.
  
  Example:
    > @va me=[add(1,1)] %# %n %%#
    Set
    > say [subeval(%# %N %%# [sub(1,1)])]
    You say "#123 Tester %# [sub(1,1)]"
    > say [subeval(%# %N %%# [sub(1,1)],,1)]
    You say "#123 Tester #123 [sub(1,1)]"
    > say [subeval(me,va)]
    You say "[add(1,1)] #123 Tester %#"
    > say [subeval(me,va,1)]
    You say "[add(1,1)] #123 Tester #123"
  
  See Also: s(), eval(), sandbox(), ueval()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SUBJ()
  Function: subj(<object>)
 
  Returns the proper subjective pronoun (he, she, it, they) for referring to
  <object>, based on the object's Sex attribute.  You must either control
  or be near <object>.
  
  Example:
    > @sex me=male
    Set.
    > say subj(me)
    You say "he"
   
  See Also: SUBSTITUTIONS, obj(), poss(), aposs()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SUBNETMATCH()
  Function: subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>,<netmask>)
            subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>/<CIDR>)
  
  This function allows you to check wether an IP falls into a certain subnet
  or not. The function allows you to use either a format specifying the
  subnet address and netmask, or the common CIDR format.
  
  It returns 1 if the IP address is part of the subnet, 0 if it is not.
  
  Examples:
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0, 255.0.0.0) -> 1
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0, 255.255.0.0) -> 0
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0/8) -> 1
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0/16) -> 0
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SUBSTITUTIONS
  Topic: SUBSTITUTIONS
 
  All messages may contain %-substitutions, which evaluate to gender-specific
  pronouns if the player's gender is set or to other useful information.
  Information returned is based on the player that caused the message to be
  displayed, not the object that stored the message or which is running the
  action list.  The substitutions available are:
 
    %s, %S     = Name, he, she, it, they.        (subjective)
    %o, %O     = Name, him, her, it, them.       (objective)
    %p, %P     = Name's, his, her, its, their.   (possessive)
    %a, %A     = Name's, his, hers, its, theirs. (absolute possessive)
    %n, %N     = the player's name.
    %k, %K     = the player's colorized/accented name.
    %w, %W     = the target dbref# of the twinklock (if applicable)
    %r         = carriage return.
    %t         = tab character.
    %b         = space character.
    %%         = literal '%' character.
    %0-%9      = Value of positional parameter/stack location 0 through 9.
    %-<num>    = Stack 10+ that are comma delimited or if <num> specified
                 the positional stack location 0 through 999.  BANGS supported.
    %-m        = The last command executed that issued @hook.  
    %i0-%i99   = Equivalent to itext(0) through itext(99). [%il for outer]
    %i_0-%i_99 = Equivalent to inum(0) through inum(99) [%i_l for outer]
                 BANGS supported.  Note: '99' depends on recursion limit.
    %d0-%d9    = Equivalent to dtext(0) through dtext(9).  [%dl for outer]
                 Only useable with /inline only.  BANGS supported.
    %q0-%q9    = Value of registers.  Basically equivalent to [r(0)] - [r(9)].
                 Note: You may use %q<label>/%q<0> as well.  BANGS supported.
    %qa-%qz    = Extended value of registers.
    %va-%vz    = Contents of attribute va through vz.
   
    NOTE: Anything that says BANGS supported may use BANGS for the process.
          example: %-!!$22 (see if arg 22 contains a string)
                   %q<!!$0> (see if register 0 is a string)
                   %q<!!$foo> (see if register with label 'foo' is a string)
                   %i!!$0 (see if iter()'s itext(0) is a string)
                   %d!!$0 (see if @dolist/inline's dtext(0) is a string)
  
{ 'help substitutions2' for more }



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



substitutions2
    %#      = Database number of the object that caused the message to be
              displayed or the action list to be run.
    %:      = Database object-id of the object that caused the message to be
              displayed or the action list to be run.
    %l      = Database number of the location of the object that caused the
              message to be displayed or the action list to be run.
    %!      = Database number of the object holding the message or running
              the action list.
    %@      = Database number of the object immediately calling %! (Caller).
              This number starts as the same as %#, but can be affected by
              u()-type functions, zones, and @function.
    %+      = Show the total arguments a function received.
    %?      = Show current function invocation as well as current nest levels.
    %c      = ANSI substitution or Last Command Executed.
    %x      = ANSI substitution or Last Command Executed.
    %_      = The TRACE breakpoint marker.  See 'help %_' for more.
    %m      = ANSI substitution or Last Command Executed.

              The functionality of above subs depends on compile options:

            * ANSI substitution: It takes the next character as the ansi
              sequence and continues with that sequence till the next one
              or end of the line.  You may also specify 0x## (ie: 0x20)
              to use extended 256 colors.

            * Last Command Executed: The substitution contains the whole,
              unevaluated code of the last command executed.

    %f      = Specify template for accent handler for strings.  To see a list
              of templates, see help on the accent() function.
    %<      = Used for UNICODE (ASCII 160 through 255).  Syntax: %<###>
              This requires the ACCENT toggle to utilize.
  
  Note:  The functionality of '%c' and '%x' may be switched.  Check
         @list options to check.
  
  Note:  The functionality of '%f' is only useable if ZENTY_ANSI is enabled.
         The functionality of '%<' is only useable if ZENTY_ANSI is enabled.
         The functionality of '%<' requires the ACCENTS toggle.
   
  If the letter following the % is capitalized, the first letter of the
  result of the substitution is also capitalized.
   
  Note: %<whatever> is equivalent to [v(<whatever>)], but is more efficient.
        This _ONLY_ works for @va to @vz attributes currently.  Sorry.
  
  See Also: GENDER, V(), SHIFT(), ACCENT()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SUCCESS
  Topic: SUCCESS
 
  You successfully use a player or a thing when you take it (because you
  passed the lock).  You successfully use an exit when you go through it.
  You successfully use a room when you look around and the room is not locked
  against you.
  
  See Also: get, look, @asuccess, @lock, @osuccess, @success
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SUPER-ROYALTY
  Flag: SUPER-ROYALTY (IMMORTAL)(i)   
  
  This flag when set on a player allows them to be a hybrid wizard.  
  They can basically do anything, see anything, be anything.  The 
  only thing they can not do is set or unset this flag or directly 
  affect #1.  It's generally wise if you don't annoy these people.
  
  See Also: GUILDMASTER, ARCHITECT, COUNCILOR, ROYALTY
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SWITCH()
  Function: switch(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])
   
  The switch function compares <str> against <pat1>, <pat2>, etc (allowing *
  to match any number of characters and ? to match any 1 character), and
  returns the corresponding <resN> parameter for the first <patN> pattern
  that matches.  If none match, then the default result <dflt> is returned.
   
  Example:
    > say switch(c,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "C"
    > say switch(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "E"
    > say switch(cab,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "A"
    > say switch(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D)  
    You say ""
    ----- if penn_switches enabled
    > say switch(3,>=2,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
    ----- if float_switches enabled
    > say switch(2.23,>=2.22,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
  
  If configured, you may use #$ as a substition.   #$ is substituted with 
  the value of <string>. In this way, the commands in <res11>..<dflt> 
  have a short-hand way of getting at the matched value. 
  
  Note: The following config parameters effect how this functions.
        penn_switches  -- if enabled allows >, <, >=. <= for math.
        float_switches -- if enabled allows floating values as well.
  
  Refer: '@list options boolean *switch*' to check switch options.
  
  See Also: @switch, match(), case(), ifelse(), switchall()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SWITCHALL()
  Function: switchall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])
   
  The switchall function compares <str> against <pat1>, <pat2>, etc (allowing *
  to match any number of characters and ? to match any 1 character), and
  returns all corresponding <resN> parameters for all <patN> patterns
  that matches.  If none match, then the default result <dflt> is returned.
 
  Example:
    > say switchall(c,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "C"
    > say switchall(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "E"
    > say switchall(cab,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "ABC"
    > say switchall(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D)  
    You say ""
    ----- if penn_switches enabled
    > say switch(3,>=2,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
    ----- if float_switches enabled
    > say switch(2.23,>=2.22,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
  
  If configured, you may use #$ as a substition.   #$ is substituted with 
  the value of <string>. In this way, the commands in <res11>..<dflt> 
  have a short-hand way of getting at the matched value. 
  
  Note: The following config parameters effect how this functions.
        penn_switches  -- if enabled allows >, <, >=. <= for math.
        float_switches -- if enabled allows floating values as well.
  
  Refer: '@list options boolean *switch*' to check switch options.
  
  See Also: @switch, match(), case(), ifelse(), switch()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



SWITCHES
  Topic: SWITCHES
 
  Some commands have command switches associated with them that can be used
  to modify their behavior.  For instance, switches on the @ps command
  control the amount of information displayed, and switches on the @switch
  command indicate whether to perform all actionlists whose targets match
  the search string, or just the first.
  
  See Also: @list
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



T()
  Function: t(<string>)
  
  This is a TRUE BOOLEAN function.
  
  Returns a '0' if the string is null (empty), a '0', or a # followed by any
  negative number, or a string containing nothing but spaces.  
  Otherwise, it returns a '1'.
  
  Example:
    > say t()
    You say "0"
    > say t(0)
    You say "0"
    > say t(#-1)
    You say "0"
    > say t(900)
    You say "1"
    > say t(this is a test)
    You say "1"
    > say t(space(100))
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: isobjid(), isdbref(), istag(), isspace(), s()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TAG()
  Function: tag(<string>)
 
  This function returns the #dbref stored behind the tag named <string>.
  These tags get created with Rhost's tag system ( see 'wizhelp @tag' and
  'wizhelp tags' ) by admins, and can be useful to avoid having hardcoded
  #dbrefs in mushcode.
 
  These tags can also be used on-the-fly in the client, for example using
  something like 'ex tag(weather_globals)' to examine the object of which
  the #dbref is stored in the 'weather_globals' tag.
 
  If a non-existant tagname is supplied in the tag() function, it always
  returns #-1.

  NOTE: An alternative to using tag() is to look up a tag with #<tagname>
   as a replacement for #dbref. For example, "tag(weather_globals)" and
  "#weather_globals" will return the same #dbref.
 
  Also See: help wizhelp tags, wizhelp @tag, wizhelp listtags(),
            wizhelp tagmatch()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



take
  Command: take[/<switch>] <object>
           take[/<switch>] <exit>
           take[/<switch>] <object>'s <sub-object>
 
  The first form picks up <object> from your location and adds it to your
  inventory.  It will fail if the object is locked against you, or if you
  are inside a player or object that you don't control and which isn't
  set ENTER_OK.
 
  The second form takes an exit from your location and adds it to you.
  Anyone inside you may then use the exit to travel to the exit's destination.
  You may take exits that you own, and exits owned by others in locations that
  you own.
 
  The third form takes <sub-object> from <object> and adds it to your
  inventory.  <object> must be ENTER_OK and <sub-object> must not be locked
  against you for this to work.  The lock on <object> is not checked.
  
{ 'help take2' for more }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



take2
  The following switch is recognized:
     /quiet   - Don't perform the @osucc/@asucc or @ofail/@afail attributes
                on the target object.  This switch only works if you control
                the object.
 
  <object> and <sub-object> may be either players or things.
  'get' is the same as 'take'.
  
  See Also: drop, @afail, @asucc, @fail, @ofail, @osucc, @succ, ENTER_OK,
            FAILURE, SUCCESS
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TAN()
  Function: tan(<number> [,<units>])
   
  Returns the tangent of <number>, expressed in radians.
  
  You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians,
  (g)radians, or (d)egrees.  (r)adians are the default.
   
  Examples:
    > say tan(0)
    You say "0"
    > say tan(1)
    You say "1.557408"
    > say tan(fdiv(pi(),4))
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), sin(), ctu(), 
            cosh(), sinh(), tanh()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TANH()
  Function: tanh(<number> [,<units>])
  
  Returns the hyperbolic tangent of <number>, expressed in radians.
 
  You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians,
  (g)radians, or (d)egrees.  (r)adians are the default.
  
  Examples:  
    > say tanh(0)
    You say "0"
    > say tanh(1)
    You say "0.761594"
    > say tanh(fdiv(pi(),4))
    You say "1.324609"

  See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), sin(), ctu(), 
            cosh(), sinh() 



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



taste
  Command: taste [<object>]
  Displays the tastes of <object>, or the location you're in if you don't
  specify an object.  Specifying object as <name> or #<dbref> or 'me' or
  'here' is legal.  You can also use taste to taste objects held by other
  people.  Just use 'taste <person>'s <object>'.
  
  See Also: look, smell, touch, listen, @staste, @sataste, @sotaste
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TEL()
  Function: tel(<obj> [<obj2>...],<loc> [<loc2>...] [,<silent>])
  
  This function works like @tel/list works.  It will teleport one or
  more objects to one or more destinations.  It follows the same 
  permissions and restrictions that @tel will follow.  The SIDEFX flag
  is required for this function.  
  
  The value of the optional argument 'silent' can be either 0 or 1. If
  set to 1 then the attributes 'atport', 'otport', 'oxtport' and 'tport'
  are not evaluated.
  
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  The last example teleports you to #0, bob to #2, and joe to #4.
  
  Example:
  > say tel(me,#0)
  You say ""
  The Beginning(#0)
  A simple room
  > @tel/list me=#0
  The Beginning(#0)
  A simple room
  > say tel(me bob joe,#0 #2 #4)
  You say ""
  
  See Also: @tel, move(), SIDEEFFECTS
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TELOK
  Flag: TELOK([T])   
  
  The TELOK flag is used to enable bitted players (staff)
  the ability to set up so that they can be teleported around as if they
  were a mortal.  This is handy in testing code where @teleport is used.
  
  See Also: JUMP_OK, @teleport
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TEMPLATE()
  Function: template(<string>, <arg0> [,<arg1>, ..., <arg9>])
  
  This function will take an input string <string> as the template string
  and do substitution based on the arguments you pass to it.  It will
  walk through each of the arguments one character at a time and replace
  the specified characters in the template.  The following characters
  specify each of the template replacements in question:
  
    1 or more 0's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg0
    1 or more 1's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg1
    1 or more 2's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg2
    1 or more 3's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg3
    1 or more 4's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg4
    1 or more 5's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg5
    1 or more 6's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg6
    1 or more 7's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg7
    1 or more 8's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg8
    1 or more 9's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg9
  
  You may have any order of substitions in the template.  You may
  use numbers that have no arguments.  In such a case the template will
  be replaced with a space character.  If the argument is shorter than
  the number of substitutions in the template, spaces are used as filler.
  
  Tabs will be replaced with a single space. 
  
  This function is ansi and accent aware.
  
  Examples:
    > say template(test <0123> test <0123> test,aaaaaaa,bbbbbbb,cccccc,dddddd)
    You say "test <abcd> test <abcd> test"
    > say template(test 001 wheee 100,----,<>)
    You say "test --< wheee >--"
    > think template(>>> 000000 <<<%r>>> 000000 <<<,abcde%rtuvwy)
    >>> abcde  <<<
    >>> tuvwy  <<<
  
  See Also: printf(), edit(), regedit(), template()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TEMPLE
  Flag: TEMPLE(T)  
  
  The TEMPLE flag is no longer a part of RhostMUSH. Check +help
  for information on +sacrifice.
  
  See Also: score
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TERSE
  Flag: TERSE(t)
   
  If you are set TERSE then you are not shown the description, success/failure
  messages, contents, or exits of locations you enter.  You must use the LOOK
  or EXAMINE commands to see this information.
   
  Others in the location still get the osucc/ofail messages and the asucc or
  afail command list is still run.
  
  If this is set on a ROOM, then the room will behave as if the person 
  entering is set TERSE.
   
  See Also: examine, look, MYOPIC
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TESTLOCK()
  Function: testlock(<key>, <target> [,<type>])
            testlock(<key>, <target1> [... <targetN>], <type>, <sep>[, <osep>])
  
  The first example of the testlock function will evaluate a lock that you 
  pass against the target <target>.  It will evaluate permissions based 
  on the enactor.
  
  The second example of the testlock function will evaluate a lock that you
  pass against a list of target(s).  It will return each target's dbref#
  based on the <key> and only evaluates <key> once for quicker processing.
  You may specify an optional <sep> seperator, or leave blank for a default
  of a space.  An optional <osep> for an output seperator may be specified
  or it defaults to what the <sep> value is.
  
  The key <key> may be any normal key found in locks.  Please see
  'help @lock' for more information on how locks work and keys available.
  
  You may specify an optional type <type> for specialized locks that
  may require a subtype.  Following types are allowed:
    0 - default lock.  Neither a $command nor a ^listen
    1 - $command lock
    2 - ^listen lock
  
  Examples:
    > say testlock(*tester&&!*tester,*tester)
    You say "0"
    > say testlock(*tester,*tester)
    You say "1"
    > say testlock(*tester|*bob,*tester *bob *foo,,%b)
    You say "#123 #234"
  
  See Also: lockencode(), lockdecode(), lockcheck(), lock(), elock(), @lock
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



THING
  Type: THING(T)
  A thing is a type that is neither exit, room, or player type.  It is
  something that can both be carried and which can carry something.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



think
  Command: think[/<swiches>] <string>
  Returns the string to the enactor at the permission level of the enactor.
  This works just as @pemit me=<string> would work.
  
  The following switches are available:
     /noansi   - Show the string literally and don't process ansi.  Only
                 useful with ZENTY_ANSI enabled (at compiletime).
    
  See Also: @pemit, @emit, say, pose
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



throw
  Command: throw[/<switch>] <object>
           throw[/<switch>] <exit>
 
  The first form removes <object> from your inventory and puts it in your
  location, except for the following special cases: Dropping a STICKY thing
  sends it home, and dropping a thing in a room with a drop-to sends the
  thing to the drop-to location.
 
  The second form removes <exit> from your list of exits and adds it to the
  list of exits for the current location.  Anyone in the same location as
  you may then use the exit to travel to the exit's destination.  You can
  only drop exits when you own the location where you are dropping them.
 
  The following switch is recognized:
     /quiet   - Don't perform the @odrop/@adrop attributes on the dropped
                 object.  This switch only works if you control the object.
 
  'drop' is the same as 'throw'.
  
  See Also: get, @adrop, @drop, @odrop, DROP-TO, STICKY
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



time functions
  Function Lists: Time Functions.
     
  convsecs()    - Converts Unix seconds to a time string.
  convtime()    - Converts a time string to Unix seconds.
  ptimefmt()    - Performs time formatting, PennMUSH style.
  secs()        - Returns the current time in Unix seconds.
  singletime()  - Converts seconds to a single time element.
  time()        - Returns the current time, formatted as a string.
  timefmt()     - Returns the current, or a specified time, formatted.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIME()
  Function: time()
 
  Gives you the current time.
  WARNING!  This is the time on the machine that the mud is running on, and
  not where you are.
 
  Example:
    > say time()
    You say "Thu Dec 19 09:48:06 1991"
  
  See Also: convsecs(), convtime(), secs(), msecs()
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT ADVANCED
     The advanced syntax of the timefmt format string adds the ability to 
  do special processing for 0 valued fields. The new format sequence looks 
  like: $[PROCOPT][-][FIELDWIDTH]FORMATSPEC
  
     The PROCOPT character is one of the following:
        '!' - Don't print field if value is 0
        '~' - Don't print field if value is 0, but pad w/ spaces to fld width
        '@' - Only print field if current field value or a previous
              field value was not 0
        '#' - Only print field if current field value or a previous
              field value was not 0, but pad w/ spaces to fld width
  
     If a field is not printed, the copying of any literal text following
  the format specifier is suppressed until the next format sequence at which
  point copying is turned back on. You can turn the copying function back on
  at any point in the literal text which follows a sequence with a PROCOPT
  by repeating the same PROCOPT character at the point in the literal text
  which you want copying to be always on. 
  
  See Also: timefmt advanced2, timefmt advanced example, timefmt escapes
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT ADVANCED EXAMPLE
  The following examples take an elapsed time (which is hard coded as the
  second argument for illustration purposes) and format it in such a way
  that any fields which are irrelevant are eliminated. Several examples
  are shown with the same format string and different <secs> argument to 
  illustrate how the output changes depending on this input. Note the 
  '#' character following 'secs' in the format string, this ensures
  that even if the $#G field is 0 and the 'secs' text is not printed that
  the ' <-' text will still be printed.
  
    timefmt(Elapsed -> $#2c days $#2X hours $#2F mins $#G secs# <-, 111111111)
    OUTPUT: Elapsed -> 12 days  0 hours 11 mins 51 secs <-
  
    timefmt(Elapsed -> $#2c days $#2X hours $#2F mins $#G secs# <-, 11111)
    OUTPUT: Elapsed ->          3 hours  5 mins 11 secs <-
  
    timefmt(Elapsed -> $#2c days $#2X hours $#2F mins $#G secs# <-, 1111)
    OUTPUT: Elapsed ->                  18 mins 31 secs <-
  
  Now note how the output changes with the '@' PROCOPT used instead of '#':
    timefmt(Elapsed -> $@2c days $@2X hours $@2F mins $@G secs@ <-, 1111)
    OUTPUT: Elapsed -> 18 mins 31 secs <-
  
  The '~' and '!' PROCOPT characters operate similarly but they only pay
  attention to the current field being 0 or not.
  
  See Also: timefmt codelist
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT ADVANCED2
  With the '~' and '#' PROCOPT types, any literal text which was turned 
  off by a 0 value field will be substituted by spaces. This keeps text 
  aligned in columns. Should one of the PROCOPT characters be needed as 
  a literal text character following a field that contains a PROCOPT, 
  the character can be escaped by doubling it, IE '@@' would print '@'
  if it was embedded in text which followed a sequence like $@G.
  
  See Also: timefmt advanced example, timefmt escapes
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT CODELIST
  Following codes exist for formatting for timefmt(<format>,<time-in-secs>)
  
  Code Type              Range         Code Type            Range
  ---- --------------    ------------  ---- --------------  ------------------
  H    hour of day       1 - 12        A    Weekday (long)  Sunday - Saturday
  h    military day      0 - 23        a    Weekday (short) Sun - Sat
  T    minute in hour    0 - 59        W    Weekday (num)   0 - 6
  S    sec. in min.      0 - 59        B    Month (long)    January - December
  P    Time of day       AM - PM       b    Month (short)   Jan - Dec
  p    Time of day       am - pm       M    Month (number)  1 - 12
  Z    Elapsed years     0 - ????      D    Day of month    1 - 31
  E    Months in years   0 - 12        J    Day of year     1 - 366
  e    Elapsed months    0 - ????      Y    Year (four dig) 0 - ????
  C    Days in months    0 - 31        y    Year (two dig)  0 - ??
  d    Days in weeks     0 - 6         I    Seconds offset from GMT time
  w    Weeks in month    0 - 4         z    Returns '1' if daylight savings
  u    Years in century  0 - 99        i    Returns the timezone abbreviation
  U    Century in Mill   0 - 9         N    Returns the longname of timezone
  m    Elapsed Millenium 0 - ????      n    Return the shortname of timezone
 *c    Elapsed days      0 - ????      t    Seconds offset of existing timezone
 *X    Hours in day      0 - 24       *!    Don't print field if value is 0
  x    Elapsed hours     0 - ????      ~    Pad with space but not if value 0
 *F    Mins. in hours    0 - 60        @    Prnt if value or prev. value not 0
  f    Elapsed mins.     0 - ????      #    Pad with spc if val/prev val not 0
  G    Secs. in minute   0 - 60       *0-9  Format column with # allignment   
  g    Elapsed secs.     0 - ????      $    Use special code (this list)     
  
  Note: Codes with a '*' were used in the example that follows.
  
{ help timefmt codelist2 for an example with great details }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT CODELIST2
  Syntax:   timefmt($<code> $<code> ... $<code>,<time-in-seconds>)
  
  Example:  ---[timefmt($!2cd$02X:$02F,conn(me))]---
  Output:   --- 3d12:03---
  
  Description: This tells to format the time and to display the day field only
               if this value is non-zero, then return the hours and minutes, 
               in a time format (IE: ##:## - the 02 says pad with zeroes a 
               total of two spaces no matter the result).  It then passes the 
               total time you were connected (the conn() function) into the 
               format you specified for timefmt(). Broken up, these codes are:
  
  Details:  $!2cd - $ tells timefmt() it's a special timefmt() code.
                    ! tells it to not print this field if zero
                   2c tells it to print a two character field and pad with
                      a space if the value is less than two characters.
                      If you use $!02cd it would return '03d' instead of ' 3d'
            $02X  - $ tells timefmt() it's a special timefmt() code.
                  02X tells it to print the hour field and pad with zeroes if
                      the total character count is less than two. IE: '06'
            $02F  - $ tells timefmt() it's a special timefmt() code.
                  02F tells it to print the minute field and pad with zeroes 
                      if the total character count is less than two. IE: '12'
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT DATE
  The following format specifiers are available for processing the <secs>
  argument as calendar time for purposes of displaying dates. Calendar
  time is the number of seconds since 0:00 1/1/70 such as that returned by
  the secs() function.
  
  SPEC   DESC                     RANGE              NOTE
  'A'    Weekday long name        Sunday..Saturday
  'a'    Weekday short name       Sun..Sat
  'W'    Weekday number           0..6               0 = Sunday
  'B'    Month long name          January..December
  'b'    Month short name         Jan..Dec
  'M'    Month number             1..12
  'D'    Day of month             1..31
  'J'    Day of year              1..366
  'Y'    Year                     0..????
  'y'    Year (two digit)         0..99
  
  See Also: timefmt examples, secs(), msecs()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT ELAPSED
  The following format specifiers are available for processing the <secs>
  argument as elapsed time. An example of elapsed time would be those
  number of seconds returned by the conn() function.
  
  SPEC   DESC                           RANGE     NOTE
  'm'    Elapsed Millenium              0..????
  'U'    Elapsed Century in Millenium   0..9
  'u'    Elapsed years in Century       0..99
  'Z'    Elapsed years                  0..????   Uses 365 day years
  'E'    Elapsed months in year         0..12     Uses 31 day months/365 days
  'e'    Elapsed months absolute        0..????   Uses 31 day months
  'C'    Elapsed days in month          0..31     Uses 31 day months
  'w'    Elapsed weeks in month         0..4
  'd'    Elapsed days in week           0..6
  'c'    Elapsed days absolute          0..????
  'X'    Elapsed hours in day           0..24     
  'x'    Elapsed hours absolute         0..????
  'F'    Elapsed minutes in hour        0..60
  'f'    Elapsed minutes absolute       0..????
  'G'    Elapsed seconds in minute      0..60
  'g'    Elapsed seconds absolute       0..????
  
  See Also: timefmt examples, conn()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT ESCAPES
  To cause the timefmt function to output a '$' character it must be
  repeated twice, example:
    @emit timefmt($$MONEY$$ at $H O'clock,secs())
    SAMPLE OUTPUT: $MONEY$ at 3 O'clock
  
  ADVANCED TIMEFMT ESCAPES
  To cause the timefmt function to output a PROCOPT character from within
  literal text which follows a format sequence which also contains the
  needed PROCOPT character it must be repeated twice. Otherwise, the character
  is a special signal to the timefmt function to tell it that even if a
  field was suppressed due to a 0 value field that you want to override the
  conditional processing for the literal text which follows the PROCOPT
  character. Example:
    @emit timefmt($!g Seconds Elapsed Dude!! Way to go.,conn())
    SAMPLE OUTPUT: 5 Seconds Elapsed Dude! Way to go.
  
  If the '!' character was not doubled in the above example, and the
  $g field equated to 0, then the output would go like this:
    @emit timefmt($!g Seconds Elapsed Dude! Way to go.,0)
    SAMPLE OUTPUT:  Way to go.
  
  See Also: timefmt advanced
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT EXAMPLES
    Wordy time and date:
      @emit timefmt($A $B $2D\, $04Y $02H:$02T $P and $02S seconds, secs())
      SAMPLE OUTPUT: Monday January 20, 1997 03:05 AM and 55 seconds
  
    A week-long calendar starting today including Julian date:
      @emit nsiter(lnum(7),timefmt($a $b $02D $04Y \\[$04Y.$03J\\], 
      add(secs(),mul(86400,##)))%r)
      SAMPLE OUTPUT: Mon Jan 20 1997 [1997.020]
                     Tue Jan 21 1997 [1997.021]
                     Wed Jan 22 1997 [1997.022]
                     Thu Jan 23 1997 [1997.023]
                     Fri Jan 24 1997 [1997.024]
                     Sat Jan 25 1997 [1997.025]
                     Sun Jan 26 1997 [1997.026]
  
    Mimicking the time() function:
      @emit timefmt($a $b $2D $02h:$02T:$02S $04Y,secs())
      SAMPLE OUTPUT: Mon Jan 20 03:20:39 1997
  
    Elapsed time such as displayed on WHO in 'On For' column:
      @emit timefmt($!2cd$02X:$02F,conn(me))
      SAMPLE OUTPUT:  3d12:03
      NOTE: This example uses advanced features, see: help timefmt advanced
  
  See Also: timefmt advanced
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT SYNTAX
     The timefmt format string can contain two types of data. First it can
  contain literal text which is mearly copied to the function's output.
  Second it can contain format sequences. Every format sequence in the
  format string describes a field to be filled in by the timefmt function.
  Fields are by default variable width and right justified.
  A format sequence begins with a '$' character and is followed by an 
  optional left justification character ('-'),
  a field width, and a mandatory format specifier. The syntax can be
  described visually as follows: $[-][FIELDWIDTH]FORMATSPEC
  
     A field width is specified as a sequence of digits representing the
  required width of the field. If a field width number begins with a 
  '0' the field will be zero padded, the default is to pad with spaces.
  
     An example of a format sequence would be '$-5M' which would print the
  month name left justified in a field with a width of 5. Should the month
  name be longer than 5 then the name will be truncated.
  
  See Also: timefmt syntax2
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT SYNTAX2
     Should it be necessary to use a '$' without wishing it to be interpreted
  as the start of a format sequence, use two '$' characters in a row as in
  '$$'. These two will be compressed into one literal '$'.
  
     There are other advanced features in the syntax which are not described
  here so as not to confuse the basic topic.
  
  See Also: timefmt, timefmt advanced, timefmt escapes
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT TIME
  The following format specifiers are available for processing the <secs>
  argument as calendar time for purposes of displaying the time. Calendar
  time is the number of seconds since 0:00 1/1/70 such as that returned by
  the secs() function.
  
  SPEC   DESC                     RANGE
  'H'    Hour of day              1..12
  'h'    Hour of day              0..23
  'T'    Minute in hour           0..59
  'S'    Second in minute         0..59
  'P'    AM or PM                 AM/PM
  'p'    am or pm                 am/pm
  
  See Also: timefmt examples, secs(), msecs()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT TIMEZONE
  Following are codes used specifically for timezone manipulation and 
  identification.
  
  SPEC   DESC                           RANGE     NOTE
  'z'    Daylight Savings Toggle        0..1      Boolean to show if active
  't'    Offset of MUSH local TZ        0..?      Offset in secs of current TZ
  'I'    Offset from GMT time           0..?      Offset in secs from GMT
  'i'    Abbreviation of Timezone       XYZ       
  'N'    Timezone Longname              <str>     Returns the Timezone Name
  'n'    Timezone Shortname             <str>     Returns geographical area
  
  See Also: timefmt codelist



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TIMEFMT()
  Function: timefmt(<format string>, <secs> [,<output timezone>])
  
  Uses the provided <format string> to output the <secs> in many useful
  ways. The function can be used to interpret <secs> as calendar time,
  or as elapsed time. Due to the many capabilities of this function,
  help for it is broken up into several sections.
  
  You may specify an optional output timezone for the time.  For a
  list of timezones, please see 'help timezone list'.
  
  ALL AVAILABLE CODES:  help timefmt codelist  (very handy!)
  FORMAT SYNTAX:        help timefmt syntax
  TIME FORMATS:         help timefmt time
  DATE FORMATS:         help timefmt date
  ELAPSED TIME FORMATS: help timefmt elapsed
  EXAMPLES:             help timefmt examples
  ESCAPE SEQUENCES:     help timefmt escapes
  TIMEZONE FORMATS:     help timefmt timezone
  
  See Also: time(), singletime(), ptimefmt(), timezone list
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]

  Zone   Zone Name                           Zone Location    UTC/GMT Offset
  ------ ----------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------

timezone list3
  Zone   Zone Name                           Zone Location    UTC/GMT Offset
  ------ ----------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------
  CLST   Chile Summer Time                   South America    UTC - 3 hours
  CLT    Chile Standard Time                 South America    UTC - 4 hours
  COT    Colombia Time                       South America    UTC - 5 hours
  CST    Central Standard Time               North America    UTC - 6 hours
  CST1   Central Standard Time               Central America  UTC - 6 hours
  CST2   Central Standard Time               Australia        UTC + 9:30 hours
  CST3   China Standard Time                 Asia             UTC + 8 hours
  CST4   Cuba Standard Time                  Caribbean        UTC - 5 hours

[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOBIN()
  Function: tobin(<number>)
  
  Todec converts the inputted number into binary.  The following formats
  are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 
        0<number>   - used to specify an octal number.      (base 8)
        0b<number>  - used to specify a binary number.      (base 2)
        <number>    - used to specify standard decimal.     (base 10)
  
  Examples:
    > say tobin(011)
    You say "00000000000000000000000000001001"
    > say tobin(3)
    You say "00000000000000000000000000000011"
    > say tobin(0x11)
    You say "00000000000000000000000000010001"
 
  See Also: tohex(), tooct(), todec()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TODEC()
  Function: todec(<number>)
  
  Todec converts the inputted number into decimal.  The following formats
  are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 
        0<number>   - used to specify an octal number.      (base 8)
        0b<number>  - used to specify a binary number.      (base 2)
        <number>    - used to specify standard decimal.     (base 10)
  
  Examples:
    > say todec(011)
    You say "9"
    > say todec(0b11)
    You say "3"
    > say todec(0x11)
    You say "17"
 
  See Also: tohex(), tooct(), tobin()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOGGLE LIST
  Toggle                  Toggle                  Toggle
  ----------------------- ----------------------- -------------------------
  MONITOR                 VANILLA_ERRORS          NO_ANSI_EX
  CPUTIME                 NOTIFY_LINK             NO_ANSI_PLAYER
  NO_ANSI_THING           NO_ANSI_ROOM            NO_ANSI_EXIT
  ZONE_AUTOADD            ZONE_AUTOADDALL         BRANDY_MAIL
  EXTANSI                 PENN_MAIL               MAIL_STRIPRETURN
  VPAGE                   MAIL_NOPARSE            MUXPAGE
  NOZONEPARENT            NOGLOBPARENT            VARIABLE
  KEEPALIVE               NOISY                   ZONECMDCHK
  ACCENTS                 MAILVALIDATE            SAFELOG
  
  For information on a particular toggle, type 'help <togglename>'.
  If the name of a toggle is similar to the name of another help
  entry you may need to add the word 'toggle'. As in 'help monitor toggle'.
  
  See Also: @toggle
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



toggle()
  Function: toggle(<object>,[!]<toggle>)
  
  The toggle() function is a side-effect for the @toggle command.  It can
  only be used to set and remove toggles.  It follows the same permissions
  and restrictions of the command.  The SIDEFX flag is required to use
  toggle().
  
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > @toggle me=vpage
  Set.
  > say toggle(me,vpage)
  You say ""
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOGGLES
  Topic: TOGGLES
  
  Toggles may be set on objects to alter the way the mush treats them.
  They are similar to flags, but are usually of a more minor 
  consequence. To set or unset a toggle, the @toggle command is used.
  For a list of toggles see 'help toggle list'.
  
  See Also: @toggle, toggle list 
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOHEX()
  Function: tohex(<number>)
  
  Todec converts the inputted number into hexidecimal.  The following 
  formats are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 
        0<number>   - used to specify an octal number.      (base 8)
        0b<number>  - used to specify a binary number.      (base 2)
        <number>    - used to specify standard decimal.     (base 10)
  
  Examples:
    > say tohex(017)
    You say "F"
    > say tohex(0b11)
    You say "3"
    > say tohex(-1)
    You say "FFFFFFFF"
 
  See Also: todec(), tooct(), tobin()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOOCT()
  Function: tooct(<number>)
  
  Tooct converts the inputted number into octal.  The following formats
  are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 
        0<number>   - used to specify an octal number.      (base 8)
        0b<number>  - used to specify a binary number.      (base 2)
        <number>    - used to specify standard decimal.     (base 10)
  
  Examples:
    > say tooct(11)
    You say "13"
    > say tooct(0b11)
    You say "3"
    > say tooct(0x10)
    You say "20"
 
  See Also: tohex(), todec(), tobin()

[TOP]
[NEXT]

[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOTCMDS()
  Function: totcmds(<player>)
  
  Totcmds returns the total number of commands issued by the player from the
  time of their creation.  
  
  Example:
    > totcmds(me)
    You say "12345" 
  
  See Also: cmds()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOTEMS()
  Function: totems(<object>)
  
  Totems returns a string consisting of the totem letters attached
  to the object.  The string is, however, just one word.  All letters
  in the 'second' tier of letters will be surrounded by []'s.  All 
  letters in the 'third' tier of letters will be surrounded by {}'s.
  
  All default letters (?) defined to toggles will be skipped.  This
  is intentional.
  
  Examples:
    > @list totems
      Totems : FOO(f) BAR([b]) BAZ(z)
    > say ltotems(me)
      You say "FOO BAR BAZ"
    > say totems(me)
      You say "fz[b]"
  
  See Also: ltotems(), flags(), toggles(), lflags(), ltoggles(),
            @totem



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOTEMSET()
  Function: totemset(<target>, <TOTEM1 TOTEM2 ... TOTEMN !TOTEM1 ... !TOTEMN>)
  
  This is a side-effect function that will set or unset totems on a target.
  The totem must be a valid totem and the target must be valid and
  controllable by the enactor.
  
  This requires the SIDEFX flag.  If you do not have access to the @totem
  command you may not use this side-effect.  If this side-effect has been
  disabled you will be unable to use this side-effect.
  
  Example:
    > say totemset(me,toteminit)
    Set.
  
  See Also: @totem, set(), toggle(), SIDEFX



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOTMATCH()
  Function: totmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
  
  This function returns all matches of <pattern> against each word of
  <string>.  This works just like match(), except it returns every
  match and location of each match.  This also understands wildcarding
  such as '?' or '*'.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than the standard space.
  
  Examples:
  > say totmatch(This is a test, test)
  You say "4"
  > say totmatch(This test is a test of totmatch. A test is fun, test)
  You say "2 5 9"
  > say totmatch(This test is silly, fred)
  You say "0"
  
  See Also: match(), nummatch(), member(), nummember(), totmember()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOTMEMBER()
  Function: member(<list>, <word>[, <delim>])
  
  Totmember takes a list and a word, and returns the position of every
  matching word in that list.  If the word does not occur in the list, 
  it will return 0.  Unlike totmatch(), totmember() does not check for
  wildcarding.  It only takes a single non-space delimited word as
  the argument for word.  totmember() is case sensitive.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  Example:
    > say totmember(This is a totmember test this is, this)
    You say "6"
    > say totmember(this is a totmember test this is, this)
    You say "1 6"
    > say totmember(This is another test, *e*)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: TOTMATCH(), MATCH(), MEMBER(), NUMMATCH(), NUMMEMBER()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TOTPOS()
  Function: totpos(<match>,<string>[,<type>])
  
  This function returns all the positions of 'match' in the given 'string'.
  This works just like pos() but will give the character placement of
  all the matches instead of the pos()'s first match.
  
  If a match is not found in string, an empty value is returned (null).
  
  The following types are available:
    1 - Tells totpos() to match ANY of the characters specified in 
        <string> and to return all the matches. 
    2 - Tells totpos() to match ANY of the characters specified in
        <string> and return the characters matched, in order, that
        were found.
  
  Note:  Options 1 and 2 are good mixes to stage and prep replacement
         with the creplace() function.
   
  Example:
    > say totpos(t,this is a test)
    You say "1 11 14"
    > say totpos(ts,this is a test,1)
    You say "1 4 7 11 13 14"
    > say totpos(ts,this is a test,2)
    You say "tsstst"
    > say totpos(t,foobles)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: numpos(), pos(), randpos(), creplace(), elementpos()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



totwildmatch()
  Function: totwildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
  
  This function returns all matches of <pattern> against each word of
  <string>.  This works just like wildmatch(), except it returns every
  match and location of each match.  String also understands wildcarding
  such as '?' or '*'.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than the standard space.
  
  Examples:
  > say totwildmatch(This is a test, test)
  You say "4"
  > say totwildmatch(This test is a test of totmatch. A test is fun, test)
  You say "2 5 9"
  > say totwildmatch(This test *e* is silly *ed, fred)
  You say "3 6"
  
  See Also: totmatch(), totmember(), wildmatch(), numwildmatch()
  
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



touch
  Command: touch [<object>]
  Displays the contours of <object>, or the location you're in if you don't
  specify an object.  Specifying object as <name> or #<dbref> or 'me' or
  'here' is legal.  You can also use touch to feel objects held by other
  people.  Just use 'touch <person>'s <object>'.
  
  See Also: look, smell, taste, listen, @stouch, @satouch, @sotouch
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TR()
  Function: tr(<string>, <find>, <replace> [,<type>])
  
  This function translates every character in <string> that exists in
  <find> to the character at an identical position in <replace>. 
  
  If you specify the <type> of '1', then tr by default will not be made 
  ansi-aware and also process strings faster without the ansi overhead.
  The default value is '0' which allows tr() to be fully ansi-aware.
   
  Ranges of characters separated by -'s are accepted. <find> and <replace> 
  must be the same length after expansion of ranges. If a character exists 
  more than once in <find>, only the last instance will be counted. The example
  below is the common ROT-13 algorithm for lower case strings, demonstrated
  with every letter explicitly listed, and with the equivalent but briefer 
  character ranges. Literal -'s can be in <find> and <replace> if they are the
  first or last characters in the arguments.
  
  Note: the config param 'ansi_default' handles if the ansi handling is 
        configured default or not.  In which case the 'type' is reversed.
   
  Examples:
    > say tr(hello,abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz,nopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklm)
      You say, "uryyb"
    > say tr(uryyb, a-z, n-za-m)
      You say, "hello"
    > say tr(This is a TEST,a-mn-zA-MN-Z,n-za-mN-ZA-M)  (rot13)
      You ssay, "Guvf vf n GRFG"
  
  See also: merge(), foreach(), garble(), creplace(), edit(), editansi()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRACE
  Flag: TRACE(T)
 
  When a thing is set TRACE, it will report to its owner the result of all
  substitutions that it performs that change the original string.  The order
  for displaying nested evaluations (such as when evaluating the arguments to
  a function) is a site-selected configuration parameter.
  
  You may specify a TRACE_GREP attibute on yourself (&TRACE_GREP me=<string>)
  if you wish to have a specific piece of code in trace output which matches
  the trace output return in red the match.
   
  Example:
  > @set object = trace
  > @va object = say The result is [add(4,mul(3,%0))].
  > @trig object/va = 7
  object(#322)} '%0' -> '7'
  object(#322)} 'mul(3,%0)' -> '21'
  object(#322)} 'add(4,mul(3,%0))' -> '25'
  object(#322)} 'The result is [add(4,mul(3,%0))].' -> 'The result is 25.'
  object says "The result is 25."
  
{ 'help trace2' for more } 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRACE()
  Function: trace(<value>)
  
  This function controls the TRACE flag on the object executing the function.
  If the value is 0, the TRACE flag is removed. If the value is non-0 then
  the TRACE flag is set.
  
  This function can be used to selectively turn on trace output for a piece
  of MUSH code. This can help to avoid the often spammy output of trace.
  
  You may specify a TRACE_GREP attibute on yourself (&TRACE_GREP me=<string>)
  if you wish to have a specific piece of code in trace output which matches
  the trace output return in red the match.
   
  Example: (line 2 wrapped)
    > &broken object=[add(3,mul)(3,7))]
    > &test object=$testme *:@emit I am [trace(1)][u(me/broken)][trace(0)][swi
      tch(%0,0,zero,non-zero)].
    > testme 0
   
  In this example you'll see trace output only for the u() of the broken 
  attribute. You will not see trace output for the @emit or the switch().
  However, if the TRACE flag was set on the object prior to execution, then
  you would see trace output for everything up to the trace(0) call.
  
  You may specify a TRACETAB attribute that contains a number between 0-10
  to indent related trace output.
  
  See Also: %_, TRACE, VERBOSE, PUPPET, chktrace()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



trace2
  When trace output is displayed in top-down order (final evaluation first,
  followed by the 'smaller' evaluations needed to perform it), then the total
  number of trace output lines that may be produced by an evaluation is limited
  to 200.  Bottom-up trace output is not limited.
  
  You may set a TRACETAB attribute to a value between 0 and 10 to indent 
  related trace output if you prefer that.
   
  You may use LABELS (help @label and help %_) for advanced tracing.
   
  See Also: VERBOSE, PUPPET, %_, trace(), chktrace(), TRACETAB



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRACE_COLOR
  Topic: SUBSTITUTIONS (CONTINUED)
  Syntax: %_<label>      -- enables debugging if <label> is in TRACE attribute.
          %_<-label>     -- disables debugging for last named <label>
          %_<->          -- disables debugging for last defined label
          %_<off>        -- disables all debugging
          %_<!list>      -- List current stack, in-use stack, and all labels.
          %_<!shortlist> -- List current stack and in-use stack.
  
  You may use the attribute TRACE_COLOR to set a standard color for your
  labels.   For instance, &TRACE_COLOR object=+purple.  You may specify 
  colors by label as &TRACE_COLOR_<label> object=+orange.  Like 
  &TRACE_COLOR_123.  This will fall back on 'TRACE_COLOR' if the by 
  label isn't found.
  
  You may specify a TRACE_GREP attibute on the enactor 
  (&TRACE_GREP object=<string>) if you wish to have a specific piece 
  of code in trace output which matches the trace output return in red 
  the match.  If the TRACE_GREP attribute is attribute-set REGEXP, 
  it will take the string as a regexp match.
  
  Keep in mind, the various &TRACE attributes need to be on the executor,
  not the object enacting the command.  It will behave like the TRACE flag.
  So all attributes (like &TRACE) need to be on the target that you 
  have the labels on.
   
  Examples:
    > &TRACE me=123
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<-123>[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<off>[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
    > &TRACE_COLOR me=+orange
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<off>[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<->[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
  
  In the last two examples, the 123 inside the []'s would have been orange.
  
  See 'help %_vars' for variables used with trace label debugging.
  
  See Also: SUBSTITUTIONS, TRACE, trace(), @label, ruler()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRACE_GREP
  Topic: SUBSTITUTIONS (CONTINUED)
  Syntax: %_<label>      -- enables debugging if <label> is in TRACE attribute.
          %_<-label>     -- disables debugging for last named <label>
          %_<->          -- disables debugging for last defined label
          %_<off>        -- disables all debugging
          %_<!list>      -- List current stack, in-use stack, and all labels.
          %_<!shortlist> -- List current stack and in-use stack.
  
  You may use the attribute TRACE_COLOR to set a standard color for your
  labels.   For instance, &TRACE_COLOR object=+purple.  You may specify 
  colors by label as &TRACE_COLOR_<label> object=+orange.  Like 
  &TRACE_COLOR_123.  This will fall back on 'TRACE_COLOR' if the by 
  label isn't found.
  
  You may specify a TRACE_GREP attibute on the enactor 
  (&TRACE_GREP object=<string>) if you wish to have a specific piece 
  of code in trace output which matches the trace output return in red 
  the match.  If the TRACE_GREP attribute is attribute-set REGEXP, 
  it will take the string as a regexp match.
  
  Keep in mind, the various &TRACE attributes need to be on the executor,
  not the object enacting the command.  It will behave like the TRACE flag.
  So all attributes (like &TRACE) need to be on the target that you 
  have the labels on.
   
  Examples:
    > &TRACE me=123
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<-123>[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<off>[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
    > &TRACE_COLOR me=+orange
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<off>[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
    > say Debugging: [add(1,1)]%_<123>[add(2,2)]%_<->[add(3,3)]
    YourPlayerName(#12345) [123]} 'add(2,2)' -> '4'
    You say "Debugging: 246"
  
  In the last two examples, the 123 inside the []'s would have been orange.
  
  See 'help %_vars' for variables used with trace label debugging.
