  See Also: SUBSTITUTIONS, TRACE, trace(), @label, ruler()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRACETAB
  Topic: SUBSTITUTIONS (CONTINUED)
  Syntax: %_<label>      -- enables debugging if <label> is in TRACE attribute.
          %_<-label>     -- disables debugging for last named <label>
          %_<->          -- disables debugging for last defined label
          %_<off>        -- disables all debugging
          %_<!list>      -- List current stack, in-use stack, and all labels.
          %_<!shortlist> -- List current stack and in-use stack.
  
  The following special variables are used for %_ label debugging.
  
  TRACE            -- This is the main controller for labels.  When the
                      object running code has a label matching one
                      in this attribute, it will run debugging code
                      for that label until turned off.   This should always
                      have labels in lower case.
  
  TRACE_GREP       -- * Without the REGEXP attribute flag, it will use
                        standard direct string matching and hilight red
                        any match in your trace output.  Again, this must
                        be set on the object running code.
                      * With the REGEXP attribute flag, it uses enhanced
                        regular expression matching to hilite red any
                        matching pattern.
  
  TRACE_COLOR      -- This is the global generic color code that you wish
                      any label to have.  If there's not a label specific
                      color, this is what it will choose.  If no color
                      is selected, it just hilights it.  Again, this must
                      be set on the object running code.
  
  TRACE_COLOR_<L>  -- Where '<L>' is the name of the label.  For example
                      if your label was 'bob' the attribute name would be
                      'TRACE_COLOR_BOB'.  This will set a specific color
                      for the given label to use.  This will have priority
                      over the global TRACE_COLOR definition.
  
  TRACETAB         -- Specify how many spaces to indent on each parse
  
  See Also: SUBSTITUTIONS, TRACE, trace(), @label, ruler()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



train
  Command: train
  The train command is used to output to the player what exactly you have 
  typed.  The output is not parsed and is taken verbatim and displayed as
  is. 
  
  Example:
    > train @emit To do addition, type:  say add(1,1) = 2
    YourName types -=> @emit To do addition, type: say add(1,1) = 2
    To do addition, type: say add(1,1) = 2                         
  
  See Also: @emit, pose, @pemit, think, ]
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRANSLATE()
  Function: translate(<string>,<type>)
  
  This function, when given a 'p' or '1', will translate all special 
  characters (like tabs, returns, ansi, etc) to the proper percent
  substitutions.  When given a 's' or '0', it will convert all the special
  characters to spaces.  Please keep in mind that as RhostMUSH strips ansi
  at the function level, that this will not work as you expect with ansi!
  
  Examples:
    > @wait 0=@va me=This%t%tis%ratest
    Set.
    > say v(va)
    You say "You say "This           is
    atest"
    > say translate(v(va),p)
    You say "This%t%tis%ratest"
    > say translate(v(va),s)
    You say "this  is atest"
  
  See Also: strip(), edit(), editansi(), s(), eval(), regedit(), subeval()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRANSPARENT
  Flag: TRANSPARENT(T)
 
  If an exit is TRANSPARENT, then when you look at it you see the description
  of the room on the other side of the exit in addition to the description
  of the exit.  
  
  If a room is TRANSPARENT, it will use a long-list of exits and display them
  in the given room by showing the names of the rooms the exits link to.
  
  For example:
  A room that is not set TRANSPARENT:
    > look
    Room
    This is a description
    Obvious Exits:
    North <N>  South <S>
  
  The same room set TRANSPARENT:
    > look
    Room
    This is a description
    Obvious Exits:
    North <N> [leads to 'Room with a view']
    South <S> [leads to 'Under the carpet']
  
  See Also: @open, @dig
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



trigonometry functions
  Function Lists: Trigonometry Functions.
     
  acos()        - Returns the arc-cosine of a number in radians.
  asin()        - Returns the arc-sine of a number in radians.
  atan()        - Returns the arc-tangent of a number in radians.
  atan2()       - Returns the arc-tangent of a two numbers in radians.
  cos()         - Returns the cosine of a number in radians.
  ctu()         - Converts a trigonometric unit from  one to another.
  dist2d()      - Returns the integer distance of two Cartesian points in 2d.
  dist3d()      - Returns the integer distance of two Cartesian points in 3d.
  sin()         - Returns the sine of a number in radians.
  tan()         - Returns the tangent of a number in radians.
  vadd()        - Returns the sum of two vectors.
  vcross()      - Returns a cross product of two vectors.
  vdim()        - Returns the dimensionality of two vectors.
  vdot()        - Returns the dot product of two vectors.
  vmag()        - Returns the magnitude of a vector.
  vmul()        - Returns the result of multiplying a vector by a number.
  vsub()        - Returns the difference between two vectors.
  vunit()       - Returns an unit vector.




[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRIM()
  Function: trim(<string> [,<trim style> [,<trim character(s)>]])
 
  This function will trim trailing and/or lead characters on the string
  that you specify.  <trim character> specifies the character to trim (default
  is space), and <trim style> tells the kind of trimming to perform (default
  is trim both sides of the string).  You may specify more than one character
  for trimming.
 
  The following values for <trim style> are recognized:
      'b' :   Trim both ends of the string (default)
      'l' :   Trim the left end of the string.
      'r' :   Trim the right end of the string.
  Note: anything else specified for <trim style> will trim both sides.
 
  Example:
    > say trim(;;;Wacka;;;,,;)
    You say "Wacka"
    > say trim(%b%b%b Polly Parrot %b%b%b%b,r)
    You say "    Polly Parrot"
    > say trim(---Trim Rules!---,l,-)
    You say "Trim Rules!---"
  
  See Also: center(), ljust(), rjust(), ljc(), rjc(), s(), printf()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRREVERSE()
  Function: reverse(<string>)
            trreverse(<string>)
 
  Reverses the order of the characters of <string>.
  
  trreverse() works like reverse() except it transposes characters that 
  are reverseable.  Ergo, > to <, ] to [, } to { and so forth.
   
  Examples:
    > say reverse(This is a test)
    You say "tset a si sihT"
    > say reverse(This is a test, Really...)
    You say "...yllaeR ,tset a si sihT"
    > say reverse(A man, a plan, a canal -- Panama!)
    You say "!amanaP -- lanac a ,nalp a ,nam A"
    > say reverse(>>test<<)
    You say "<<tset>>"
    > say trreverse(>>test<<)
    You say ">>tset<<"
  
  See Also: revwords()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TRUNC()
  Function: trunc(<number>)
   
  Returns the value of <number> after truncating off any fractional value.
  <number> may be a floating point number, and an integer result is returned.
   
  Examples:
    > say trunc(5)
    You say "5"
    > say trunc(5.2)
    You say "5"
    > say trunc(5.8)
    You say "5"
    > say trunc(-5)
    You say "-5"
    > say trunc(-5.2)
    You say "-5"
  
  See Also: div(), floor(), mod(), round()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



TXLEVEL()
  Function: txlevel(<target> [,<value>])
  
  Returns a space separated list of <target>'s Tx Levels. You must control
  <target>.  If no levels are listed, nothing is returned.  If you do not 
  control the target, or if the target does not exist, '#-1' is returned.
  
  You may specify a value to set or unset if this SIDEEFFECT feature
  is enabled.  The enactor MUST be set SIDEFX for this to work.  You
  must have permission to set reality levels to use this.  Use
  listrlevels() or @list rlevel to see the levels you can set.
  
  Example:
    > say txlevel(me)
    You say "Real".
    > say txlevel(me, !real)
    You say ""
    > say txlevel(me)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: hasrxlevel(), hastxlevel(), rxlevel(), listrlevels(), chkreality()
            rxdesc()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



type()
  Function: type(<object>)
  Returns a string indicating the object type of <object>, either EXIT,
  PLAYER, ROOM, or THING.
 
  Example:
    > say type(me)
    You say "PLAYER"
    > say type(here)
    You say "ROOM"
  
  See Also: OBJECT TYPES
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



U()
  Function: u([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The u function evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the
  function or from another object you own, passing in arguments and returning
  the result.
  
  When evaluating the fetched attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and
  not the 'calling' object, and 'me' refers to the object that supplied the
  attribute.
  
  See '@list options' to see if this functionality switched with u2()'.
  This will be switched if 'u() TinyMUSH compatibility' is enabled.
   
  Examples:
    > @va me=Word is [extract(v(vb),add(%0,1),1)], arg2 is %1.
    > @vb me=This is a test of the u function.
    > say u(va,4,Testing 123)
    You say "Word is of, arg2 is Testing 123."
    > say u(va,7)
    You say "Word is function., arg2 is ."
    > say u(me/va,6,Foobar)
    You say "Word is u, arg2 is Foobar."
  
  See Also: s(), v(), get(), get_eval(), map(), ueval(), streval(),
            objeval(), @lfunction, sandbox(), subeval()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



U2()
  Function: u2([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
  
  This is nearly exactly like the original u() function except it parses
  in an object-dependant way like the old mushes.  It works by evaluating
  the function(s) by the power of the owner of the item it's on, and not
  by the power of the enactor.  
  
  This command is also very handy to keep security.
  
  See '@list options' to see if this functionality switched with u2()'.
  This will be switched if 'u() TinyMUSH compatibility' is enabled.
   
  For examples or more information, look at u()
  
  See Also: u(), u2local(), u2ldefault(), @lfunction
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



u2default()
  Function:  u2default([<obj>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
 
  Works like udefault() but uses the u2() function instead of u()
  
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <obj>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the u2() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
 
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say u2default(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say u2default(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
 
  See Also:  get(), get_eval(), u2(), default(), edefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



u2ldefault()
  Function:  u2ldefault([<obj>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
 
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <obj>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the u2local() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
 
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.  Unlike u2default(), it doesn't clobber
  %q0-%q9 registers.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say u2ldefault(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say u2ldefault(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
 
  See Also: get(), get_eval(), u(), default(), edefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



U2LOCAL()
  Function:  u2local([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The u2local() function is almost identical to u2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or another object that you control or has the same owner as you, passing
  in arguments and returning the result. When evaluating the fetched
  attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and not the 'calling' object;
  'me' refers to the object that supplied the attribute.
 
  However, unlike the u2() function, the global registers r(0) through r(9)
  (%q0 - %q9) are preserved in their initial state. This means that functions
  "below" the level of the u2() can reset global registers for temporary
  calculations, without needing to worry about "clobbering" the original
  values.
 
  This makes u2local() particularly useful for global or shared code which
  calls arbitrary u2() functions, where global register values need to be
  preserved from accidental user clobbering.
 
{ See "help u2local2" for examples. }
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



U2LOCAL2
  Example of u2local():
    > &FRUIT me=apples bananas oranges pears
    > &SUB-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,v(FRUIT))][extract(%q0,match(%q0,%0),1)]
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are delicious!)][u2local(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say u2(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas are delicious!"
 
  If SUB-FUNCTION had been called with u2() instead of u2local():
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are delicious!)][u2(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say u2(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas apples bananas oranges pears"
 
  In this second example, in SUB-FUNCTION, %q0 was set to "apples bananas
  oranges pears", so that when the u2() "returned" and TOP-FUNCTION evaluated
  %q0, this is what was printed. In the first example, u2local() reset the
  value of %q0 to its original "are delicious!"
 
  See Also:  ulocal(), u(), u2(), uldefault(), u2ldefault(), setq(), r()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UCSTR()
  Function: ucstr(<string>)
 
  Returns <string> with all letters converted to uppercase.
 
  Example:
    > say ucstr(This is a test, really!)
    You say "THIS IS A TEST, REALLY!"
  
  See Also: capstr(), lcstr()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



udefault()
  Function:  udefault([<obj>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
 
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <obj>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the u() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
 
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say udefault(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say udefault(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
 
  See Also: get(), get_eval(), u(), default(), edefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UEVAL()
  Function: ueval([<obj>/]<attr>/permission[,<arg>],...)
  
  The ueval function evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing
  the function or from another object you own, passing in arguments and
  returning the result.  In this way it works just like 'u()', except you 
  pass in a permission to specify what permission level you wish to use for
  evaluation.  It assumes the enactor (owner) of the function always succeeds.
  When evaluating the fetched attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and
  not the 'calling' object, and 'me' refers to the object that supplied the
  attribute.  For more detail on functionality, look at U().
 
  The available permission levels are CIT[IZEN], GUILD[MASTER], ARCH[ITECT],
  COUN[CILOR], ROY[ALTY], IMM[ORTAL], SUB[EVAL].  You must have the permissions 
  of the given level in order to use it else it defaults to your permission level.
  The permission must be included for the function to work.
  
  The special permission SUB[EVAL] will work like subeval() in that it will
  only evaluate substitutions on the target and not evaluate functions.
  
  Examples:
    > @set me=royalty (let's assume you're a wizard)
    > @va me=[num(*Miriar)] (the ghod player - #1)
    > say ueval(va/royalty)
    You say "#1"
    > say ueval(va/citizen)
    You say "#-1"
  
  See Also: u(), u2(), objeval(), ulocal(), u2local(), streval(), subeval(),
            sandbox()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



uldefault()
  Function:  uldefault([<obj>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
 
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <obj>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the ulocal() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
 
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.  Unlike udefault(), it doesn't clobber %q0-%q9
  registers.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say uldefault(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say uldefault(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
 
  See Also: get(), get_eval(), u(), default(), edefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ULOCAL()
  Function:  ulocal([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
   
  The ulocal() function is almost identical to u() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or another object that you control or has the same owner as you, passing
  in arguments and returning the result. When evaluating the fetched
  attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and not the 'calling' object;
  'me' refers to the object that supplied the attribute.
   
  However, unlike the u() function, the global registers r(0) through r(9)
  (%q0 - %q9) are preserved in their initial state. This means that functions
  "below" the level of the u() can reset global registers for temporary
  calculations, without needing to worry about "clobbering" the original
  values.
   
  This makes ulocal() particularly useful for global or shared code which
  calls arbitrary u() functions, where global register values need to be
  preserved from accidental user clobbering.
   
{ See "help ulocal2" for examples. }
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ULOCAL2
  Example of ulocal():
    > &FRUIT me=apples bananas oranges pears
    > &SUB-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,v(FRUIT))][extract(%q0,match(%q0,%0),1)]
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are delicious!)][ulocal(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say u(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas are delicious!"
   
  If SUB-FUNCTION had been called with u() instead of ulocal():
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are delicious!)][u(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say u(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas apples bananas oranges pears"
   
  In this second example, in SUB-FUNCTION, %q0 was set to "apples bananas
  oranges pears", so that when the u() "returned" and TOP-FUNCTION evaluated
  %q0, this is what was printed. In the first example, ulocal() reset the
  value of %q0 to its original "are delicious!"
   
  See Also:  ulocal2(), u(), u2(), uldefault(), u2ldefault(), setq(), r(),
             @lfunction
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UNESCLIST()
  Function: unesclist(<list of characters to un-escape>|<string>)
  
  This function takes an optional list of characters you wish to un-escape 
  and then un-escapes them (via removing the \ character before it) from 
  every character that you specified.  This is intended to be used with 
  weird escape situations like calling external sources.
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=Test: \'A string\' and \"anoter string\"\, I say.
    Set.
    > say unesclist('",|[v(va)])
    You say "Test: 'A string' and "anoter string", I say."
    > say unesclist('|[v(va)])
    You say "Test: 'A string' and "anoter string", I say."
  
  See Also: escape(), escapex(), esclist()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UNFINDABLE
  Flag: UNFINDABLE(U) 
  
  If a player is set UNFINDABLE, he cannot be found by 
  the loc() or room() functions.  Bummer.
  
  If a room is set UNFINDABLE, players in that room (or inside objects
  in the room) cannot be found by loc(),room(), or similiar functionality.
  
  See Also: DARK
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UNICODE SUPPORT
  Topic: UNICODE SUPPORT
  
  RhostMUSH servers can now support unicode characters. Currently this only
  supports UTF8 encoding of these characters. In order to make use of this
  feature RhostMUSH must be compiled with ZHENTY ANSI support. This works
  alongside ACCENTS support but is independent of it.
  
  For a player to see unicode characters they must enable the UTF8 toggle.
  This toggle is mutually exclusive from the ACCENTS toggle but also works
  alongside it, allowing accents sent by players with one toggle to be 
  correctly seen by the other. However, those with neither toggle will have
  these extended characters removed as normal. Similarly, unicode characters
  beyond the supported range for ACCENTS will be removed for players with
  that toggle.
  
  Unicode characters are encoded by the parser in the format %<u####> where
  the ####s represent the unicode code point for the character. 
  
  A complete list of unicode characters can be found here: 
  http://unicode.org/charts/
  
  See Also: UTF8 TOGGLE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UNPACK()
  Function: unpack(<packed number>[[,<radix>][,<penn compat flag>]])
   
  Returns the equivalent normal base-10 number of the given
  packed-number using the specified base. The default radix is 64.
  The inverse function of unpack is pack.  The radix can be between
  2 and 64.
  
  You may specify tghe PennMUSh compatable toggle (1) which will mimic Penn's
  64 bit packing algo.
   
  Examples:
    >think unpack(bVxTM)
    629126998
    >think unpack(1111,2)
    15
   
  See Also: pack(), crc32(), mask(), tobin(), tohex(), tooct(), todec(),
            packmath()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



use
  Command: use <object>
  Uses <object>.  Some objects will do interesting, useful, or dangerous
  things when used, for instance, using a camera should result in a 
  picture being taken.
  
  See Also: @ause, @ouse, @use
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



USEFUL
  Topic: USEFUL
  
  The following topics should be of greater import to learn for new users.
  
  news cmdlist          - lists all commands with the news system
  mail cmdlist          - lists all commands with the mail system
  mail write cmdlist    - lists all commands with the mail line-editor
  folder cmdlist        - lists all commands with the mail folder system
  page                  - lists differences in the page system
  goto                  - for movement (or just type the exit name)
  look                  - to look at something.  Specify optional target.
  drop                  - to drop something
  get                   - to get something
  inventory             - to see your inventory
  say                   - to say something (use " as shorthand)
  pose                  - to pose/emote something (use : as shorthand)
  @emit                 - to emit something (use \\ as shorthand)
  WHO                   - needs to be capitalized to who (unless changed)
  QUIT                  - needs to be capitalized to quit (unless changed)
  LOGOUT                - needs to be capitalized to logout (unless changed)
  
  Type 'help <topic>' for help on a particular topic.
  
  There are also differences on this platform compared to MUX/TINY.
  For these differences, please type:
  
                         help differences
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



USER ATTRIBUTES
  Topic: USER ATTRIBUTES
  
  User attributes are defined as personally designed or created attribute
  names by the user.  These can be mostly anything you want, up to the
  length of the current SBUF (32 or 64 characters) and starting with
  a-z, A-Z, ~ (if configured), # (if configured), or _ (wiz only).
  
  Attributes may not start with any other character, but after the initial
  character they are able to contain most characters up to the SBUF
  lenght.
  
  You can set these attributes with the & (or clustered >) command, or by
  using @set or set().  Individual help for each of those is available.
  
  Attribute permissions may not be possible to set based on locks that may
  exist, control of the object you're trying to set it on, or global 
  permissions prefixes that may be established.
  
  See Also: &, >, @set, set(), @cpattr, @mvattr



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



userlocks
  Userlocks are created, viewed, and checked by utilizing three functions.
  
    lockencode(<string>) --------- this will encode the lock key 
                                   (any valid key) into a 64 byte encoding 
                                   (like mime encapsulation) that you can 
                                   then store pretty much anywhere that you 
                                   want.
  
    lockdecode(<string>) --------- this will decode the specified encoded key
                                   value into the human-readable lock format. 
                                   The output will be the same as if you did 
                                   a lock() on a @lock.
  
    lockcheck(<string>,target>) -- this will compare the 64 byte encoded lock
                                   against the specified target.  It returns
                                   a '1' for success or a '0' for failure. 
                                   This works like elock() on a @lock.
  
  See Also: lockencode(), lockdecode(), lockcheck(), lock(), elock(), @lock



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UTF8 SUPPORT
  Topic: UNICODE SUPPORT
  
  RhostMUSH servers can now support unicode characters. Currently this only
  supports UTF8 encoding of these characters. In order to make use of this
  feature RhostMUSH must be compiled with ZHENTY ANSI support. This works
  alongside ACCENTS support but is independent of it.
  
  For a player to see unicode characters they must enable the UTF8 toggle.
  This toggle is mutually exclusive from the ACCENTS toggle but also works
  alongside it, allowing accents sent by players with one toggle to be 
  correctly seen by the other. However, those with neither toggle will have
  these extended characters removed as normal. Similarly, unicode characters
  beyond the supported range for ACCENTS will be removed for players with
  that toggle.
  
  Unicode characters are encoded by the parser in the format %<u####> where
  the ####s represent the unicode code point for the character. 
  
  A complete list of unicode characters can be found here: 
  http://unicode.org/charts/
  
  See Also: UTF8 TOGGLE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



UTF8 TOGGLE
  Toggle: UTF8
  
  When set on a player, and as long as ZENTY_ANSI has been compiled
  into the RhostMUSH in question, this allows the player to see
  strings including extended character sets using UTF8 encoding.
  
  You can not have the UTF8 toggle with the ACCENT toggle enabled.
  Attempting to do so will give you an error message.
   
  See Also: UNICODE SUPPORT, ACCENT TOGGLE
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



V()
  Function: v(<string>)
  The V function can be used as an alternative for percent (%) substitution
  and also as a replacement for get(me/<arg>).  If the argument is two
  characters long or longer and starts with a letter, then the object
  performing the v() call (and its parent, if necessary) is searched for the
  named attribute, and its value is returned if possible.  Otherwise, a
  percent substitution is performed on the argument (so that v(o) is
  equivalent to %o, for instance).  The percent form (%o in the previous
  example) is preferred as it is faster, and there are no longer any security
  problems associated with it.  Note that attributes with single-character
  names cannot be retrieved with v().  
  
  '#' will return the dbref# of the enactor, UNLESS there is a valid char
  after it in which it will attempt to pull the attribute.
  
  Do note that the '%' substitution for attributes only works for @va to @vz.
  
  Limitations:  v() can not call single-character attributes.  Use get() for
                any attribute with a single character.
  
  Notes: v() allows you to grab values past %9 without resorting to shift().
  
  Examples:
    > &# me=test
    Set
    > &#123 me=Test 2
    Set
    > say num(me)
    You say "#123"
    > say v(#)
    You say "#123"
    > say get(me/#)
    You say "test"
    > say v(#123)
    You say "Test 2"
  
  See Also: GENDER, SUBSTITUTION, PARENT OBJECTS, SHIFT()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VADD()
  Function: vadd(<vector>,<vector>[[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the sum of two vectors.  A vector is a list of numbers
  separated by spaces or a delimiter.  The vector lists must contain
  the same number of items or it will return an error.  You may
  specify an optional output separator.
   
  Examples:
    > think vadd(1 2 3,4 5 6)
    5 7 9
    > think vadd(0|0|0,1|2|3,|)
    1|2|3
    > think vadd(0|0|0,1|2|3,|,@)
    1@2@3
  
  See Also: vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vmag(), vcross()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VALID()
  Function: valid(<option>, <string>)
  
  This function returns 1 if <string> is valid for <option>, and 0
  if it is not.
  
  The following options are available for the valid function:
     name       - returns '1' if the string is a valid object name
     attrname   - returns '1' if the string is a valid attribute name
     playername - returns '1' if the string is a valid player name.  This 
                  also checks if the player already exists.
     password   - returns '1' if the string is a valid password.
     command    - returns '1' if string is a valid command (or alias).
     function   - returns '1' if string is a valid function.
     ufunction  - returns '1' if string is valid @function/@lfunction.
     flag       - returns '1' if string is a valid flag.
     toggle     - returns '1' if string is a valid toggle.
     qreg       - returns '1' if string is valid qreg label.
     colorname  - returns '1' if string is a valid +name for ansi.
     ansicodes  - always returns '1'.  Meant for Penn compatibility.
     timezone   - returns '1' if string is a valid timezone.
     locktype   - returns '1' if string is a valid lock switch/type.
     lockkey    - returns '1' if string is a valid string for locking.
  
  If a valid option is not specified, this function returns #-1.
  
  Examples:
    > say valid(name, Fred)
    You say "1"
    > say valid(name, )
    You say "0"
    > say valid(playername,me)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: isobjid(), isdbref(), istag(), name()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VANILLA_ERRORS TOGGLE
  Toggle: VANILLA_ERRORS
 
  When this toggle is set on an object, the mush will show that object
  the normal error message. Otherwise the mush will show something more
  creative.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VARIABLE EXITS
  Variable exits are done somewhat differently than Penn and TinyMUSH3.  First,
  it doesn't matter where the exit is linked to (though we suggest you do link
  it somewhere *grin*).  You then @toggle the exit VARIABLE.  It will then 
  check the @exitto attribute on the exit for the destination.  If the 
  destination is not a valid location ('home' or a valid dbref# that can be 
  linked to) it will fail to allow the target through the exit and return an 
  error message.
  
  See Also: @exitto, variable toggle
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VARIABLE TOGGLE
  Toggle: VARIABLE
  
  Specifies that the target exit is a 'variable' exit and that it will
  parse the @exitto attribute for it's destination location and not where
  it is currently linked to.  If the exit is @powered FULLTEL then that
  exit will be assumed to have full 'link' privialages to any valid
  location returned from @exitto.
  
  If a player sets the VARIABLE toggle on himself, then all ansi via
  Cname()/%k will show up when that player @walls, poses, or uses say.
    
  See Also: variable exits, @exitto
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VATOVZ
  Command: @va[/<switch>] <object>=<string>
           ...
           @vz[/<switch>] <object>=<string>
  
  This sets attributes VA - VZ (with @va - @vz) on the target object.
  This is in effect just like &VA or &VZ but is provided for older MUSH
  backward compatibility.
  
  Optional switches are /quiet to suppress output or /noisy to give 
  verbose output.
  
  See Also: & 
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VATTRCNT()
  Function: vattrcnt(<object> [,<type>])
  This function counts just the user-defined attributes that exist on
  an object.  User defined attributes are attributes that are set
  with the &attr object=string or @set object=attr:string commands and
  have no @<attribute> ability. (like @va, @desc, etc)
  
  If the <type> is specified to 1, it will reset the vattr count on
  the attribute.  This should never become out of sync with the true
  count on the object.  If there is a discrepency, it usually points
  to larger problems that should be brought to the attention of the
  developers.  This could be caused from improper database writes
  to disk, quota/disk limitations, or possible db corruption.
  
  Examples:
    > say vattrcnt(me)
    You say "14"
    > say attrcnt(me)
    You say "20"
    > say words(lattr(me))
    You say "20"
  
  See Also: words(), lattr(), attrcnt()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VCROSS()
  Function: vcross(<vector>,<vector>[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the cross product of two vectors. The cross product of two
  vectors is a vector.  This function may take an optional separator.
  
                          | a b c |
  (a,b,c) X (d,e,f) = det | d e f | = i(bf-ce) + j(cd-af) + k(ae-bd)
                          | i j k |
  
  where i, j, and k are taken as unit vectors in cartisian space.
   
  Examples:
  > @pemit me=vcross(1 2 3,2 3 4)
  -1 2 -1
  > @pemit me=vcross(1 2 3,2 3 4,,@)
  -1@2@-1
  
  Taken from MUX 2.0 with permission.
   
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vmag()
  
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VDIM()
  Function: vdim(<vector>[,<delimiter>])
   
  Returns the dimensionality of a vector.  For all intents and purposes
  this works just like words().
   
  Example:
    > think vdim(1 2 3 4)
    4
    > think vdim(1@2@3@4,@)
    4
  
  See Also: vadd(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vmag(), vcross()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VDOT()
  Function: vdot(<vector>,<vector>[,<delimiter>])
  
  Returns the dot product of two vectors. A dot product is the sum
  of the products of the corresponding elements of the two
  vectors, e.g. vdot(a b c,d e f) = ad + be + cf.
  The vectors must be of the same length.
  
  Example:
    > think vdot(1 2 3,2 3 4)
    20
  
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vmul(), vsub(), vmag(), vcross()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VERBOSE
  Flag: VERBOSE(v)   
  
  This flag causes all commands executed by the object having
  the flag to be sent to the owner of the object.  i.e.:
  
      @create foo
      @set foo=VERBOSE
      @force foo="Hi.
      foo] "Hi.
      foo says "Hi."
  
  See Also: TRACE, PUPPET, trace()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VERBS
  Topic: VERBS
 
  For many verbs there are three attributes that specify messages and actions
  associated with the verb in addition to the verb's built-in action.
  The attributes are named Verb, Overb, and Averb.  Verb is the message that
  the enactor sees, Overb is the message that everyone else in the same room
  as the enactor sees, and Averb is a list of commands that are run.
  These attributes may be set using the @<attribute> command, so the commands
  to set the attributes related to the 'drop' command are @drop, @odrop, and
  @adrop.
  
  See Also: @verb
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



version
  Command: version
  Displays the version of MUSH that is running and the date it was last
  rebuilt.
  
  See Also: +uptime
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VERSION()
  Function: version(<arg>)
 
  Returns a string which contains various version information for the MUSH
  you're on.
  
  Optional arguments are:
    0 - Show the version of RhostMUSH running (default)
    1 - Show the build date of RhostMUSH
 
  Example:
     > version
     RhostMUSH Version 3.5 patchlevel 0 #3
     Build date: Thu Dec  5 10:10:07 EST 1991
     > say version()
     You say "RhostMUSH Version 3.5 patchlevel 0 #3"
  
  See Also: version
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



visible()
  Function:  visible(<victim>)
  
  Returns '1' if <victim> is visible by the enactor, '0' otherwise.
  
  Example:
    > say visible(thingy)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: visiblemux(), ishidden()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



visiblemux()
  Function:  visiblemux(<object>,<victim>[/<attr>])
   
  Returns 1 if <object> can examine <victim>, or 0 otherwise. If
  <object> or <victim> do not exist, 0 is returned.
 
  If an object-attribute pair is provided, 1 is returned if <object>
  can see <attr> on <victim>. If <attr> is not present on <victim>,
  1 is returned if <object> can examine <victim>.
  
  Examples:
    > say visiblemux(#1,me)
    You say "0"
    > say visiblemux(me,me)
    You say "1"
    > say visiblemux(me,me/desc)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: ishidden(), visible()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VISUAL
  Flag: VISUAL(V)  
  
  The flag a lot of players have been waiting for. When set on
  your object, it allows other players to examine it and see all the
  object's attributes as if they owned the object. They cannot make 
  any changes to the object.  This was previously called SEE_OK in
  some MUSHes.
  
  See Also: ATTRIBUTE FLAGS
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VMAG()
  Function: vmag(<vector>[,<delimiter>]
   
  Returns the magnitude of a vector, using a euclidean distance metric.
  That is, for vector a b c d, returns sqrt(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2).
  The vectors must be the same length.
   
  Example:
    > think vmag(3 4) 
    5
  
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vcross()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VMUL()
  Function: vmul(<vector|number>,<vector|number>[[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the result of either multiplying a vector by a number,
  or the elementwise product of two vectors.  This function may take an 
  optional output separator.
  
  Examples: 
    > think vmul(1 2 3,2)      (this is a vector by number)
    2 4 6
    > think vmul(1 2 3,2 3 4)  (this is a vector by vector)
    2 6 12
    > think vmul(1@2@3,2@3@4,@,|)  (this is a vector by vector)
    2|6|12
  
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vsub(), vmag(), vcross()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VPAGE TOGGLE
  Toggle: VPAGE
  
  When set on a player, it allows them to see the aliases (if existing)
  on the list of players the page went to as well as the person who
  sent the page.  If the alias does not exist, no alias info is 
  displayed.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VSUB()
  Function: vsub(<vector>,<vector>[[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the difference between two vectors.  The vectors must be
  the same length.  This function may take an optional output
  separator.
   
  Example:
    > think vsub(3 4 5,3 2 1)
    0 2 4
    > think vsub(3 4 5,3 2 1,,@)
    0@2@4
  
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vmag(), vcross()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



VUNIT()
  Function: vunit(<vector>[[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the unit vector (a vector of magnitude 1), which points
  in the same direction as the given vector.  This function may take
  an optional output separator.
   
  Examples:
    > think vunit(2 0 0)
    1 0 0
    > think vunit(2 0 0,,@)
    1@0@0
    > think vmul(vunit(5 6 7),vmag(5 6 7))
    5 6 7
  
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vmag(), vcross()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



wanderer
  Reference: wanderer
  
  The wanderer is what shows up on the default WHO/DOING listing for the mush.
  This is in effect a reference to show you are new to the mush and have been
  on for only a short bit.  However, depending on the guidelines of the mush
  you are on, this meaning can be changed arbitrarily.  Also, the value of
  'Wanderer' in the 'Guild' field in the WHO/DOING can be changed to something
  else as well depending on the configuration on that particular RhostMUSH.
  
  There also is a flag 'wanderer' that gets set on any new player.  This will
  in effect disable all building of the player (wizard/immortal overrides
  this flag) until this flag is removed.  
  
  For wizards wanting to remove this on new player creation, please see the
  wizard help for the 'start_build' config parameter.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WHERE()
  Function: where(<object>)
 
  This function returns the "true" location of an object. You must control
  the object or be near it in order for it to work. For players and things,
  the "true" location is the normal location of the object. For exits, the
  "true" location is the source room. For rooms, it is #-1.
  
  Example:
    > say where(me)
    You say "#123"
    > say loc(me)
    You say "#123"
   
  See Also: loc(), rloc(), @whereis, @whereall
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WHILE()
  while([<uobj>/]<uattr>,[<cobj>/]<cattr>,<list>,<str>[,<delim>[,<output d>]])
  
  This function evaluates the elements of <list>, until a termination
  condition is reached or the end of the list is reached.
  
  [<uobj>/]<uattr> is an attribute or object/attribute pair, like the first
  argument of map(). The <list> is passed to that function element-by-element
  (based on the input <delim> delimiter) as %0, just as if map() were being
  called, and the output is returned <output d>-delimited, again just as if
  map() were being called.
  
  However, for each element, after that evaluation is done, a second
  evaluation is done, to check a "termination value". [<cobj>/]<cattr>
  is an attribute or object/attribute pair, again like map(), and the
  same list elements are passed to that function as %0. However, the
  result of this evaluation is not kept; instead, it is compared to
  <str>, and if it matches exactly (case-sensitive, no wildcards),
  the no further elements of the list are processed.
  
{ Continued in 'help while2'. }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WHILE2
  while([<uobj>/]<uattr>,[<cobj>/]<cattr>,<list>,<str>[,<delim>[,<output d>]])
  
                              (CONTINUED)
  
  If the contents of [<uobj>/]<uattr> and [<cobj>/]<cattr> are the
  same, the element is not evaluated twice; the result of the first
  evaluation is directly compared against <str>. (Note that the
  two object/attributes don't have to be the same -- just their
  contents need to be the same, since this function treats the
  pair like map(), not like u().)
  
  Examples:
    > &EVAL_FN me = [reverse(%0)]
    > &COND_FN me = [strlen(%0)]
    > say [while(EVAL_FN,COND_FN,foo bar meep flibble baz,4)]
    You say "oof rab peem"
    > SAY [while(EVAL_FN,COND_FN,foo|bar|meep|flibble|baz,4,|,-)]
    You say "oof-rab-peem"
  
  This function provided for TinyMUSH 3.0 compatibility.
  
  See Also: map(), step(), foreach(), iter(), inf()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



whisper
  Command: whisper <player>=<message>
  Whispers the message to the named person, if they are in the same room as
  you. No one else can see the message that you whisper.
 
  You can format the message one of several ways by specifying ':', ';', or
  '"' as the first character of the message.  ':' and ';' format the message
  as 'You sense <player> <message>', with ';' omitting the space between
  <player> and <message>.  '"' formats the message in normal whisper format
  (this is the default).
  
  See Also: page, pose, say, :, ;, "
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



who
  Command: WHO <prefix>
  Displays a list of players currently connected to the MUSH.
  The WHO report tells you how long a player has been on, how long they
  have been inactive, and what they are doing (if they have used the @doing
  command).  If <prefix> is specified, only players whose names start with
  <prefix> are listed.  There are two forms of the WHO listing.  One
  shows GUILDS (an arbitrary attribute called 'guild' on a player) and
  the other has just the basic information.  The GUILD field in the DOING
  can be optionally changed to another field.  If you see another field than
  'Guilds' the default value has been changed.
  
  Also, if enabled, you may see either a '*' or the actual bit of the staff
  when you do a WHO.
  
  Note:  WHO must be in all caps to work.
  
  See Also: @doing, DOING
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



wielded
  Command: wielded
  If alternate inventories are enabled, this command will show you what is
  currently being 'wielded' by yourself.  Things 'wielded' are identified by
  having a special wizard @toggle 'WIELDED' set on them.
  
  See Also: inventory, worn
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WILDCARDS
  Topic:  WILDCARDS [* and ?]  (also referred to as GLOBBING)
  
  Note: RhostMUSH also supports regular expressions.  Please refer to 
        'help REGEXPS'
  
  Wildcards are the standard globbing mechanism for the mush engine.  With the
  wildcards, the '*' character is considered 0 or more characters and the '?'
  character is considered a single character.  These are used primarilly in
  commands and functions that allow mulit-matching based on wild card support.
  
  Example:
    > say match(this is a test,?es*)
    You say "4"
  
  Wildcards, however, are most useful for $command substitution matching.
  When you create your own softcoded command, any argument you want
  substituted you would place a '*' or a '?' for that argument.  Each argument
  is then matched up with a numerical argument for each wildcard used.  The
  first argument being %0, second being %1, and so forth.
  
  Example:
    > &TEST1 me=$test1*:@emit Your First Test:%0
    > &TEST2 me=$test2?:@emit Your Second Test:%0
    > &TEST3 me=$test3 *:@emit Your Third Test:%0
    > test1
    Your First Test:
    > test1 abc
    Your First Test: abc  [notice the space between ':' and 'a']
    > test2
    Huh? (Type 'help' for help)  [Because ? requires 1 character exactly]
    > test2X
    Your Second Test:X
    > test2abc
    Huh? (Type 'help' for help)  [Because ? required 1 character exactly]
    > test3
    Huh? (Type 'help' for help)  [because you have a space in the command]
    > test3 abc
    Your Third Test:abc  [notice no space between ':' and 'a']
    
  { See 'help wildcards2' for clarification and extended explainations }
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WILDCARDS2
  Clarification:
    The difference between Test1 and Test3 is the fact there is a space in
    the command between the command (test1 and test3 respectively) and the
    wildcard.  For test1, when you did 'test1 abc' the space in ' abc' was
    part of the argument you passed to the command, thus it included the
    space.  In test3, you had a space as part of the requirement argument
    so it required the space then saw 'abc' as the argument.   
  
    Test2 required a single character after it.  Anything less or more than
    1 character exactly returned an error message.
  
  Additional matching:
    You may use regular expressions instead of globbing if you set the 
    attribute in question REGEXP (help attribute flag).  To use 
    regular expressions instead, please check 'help REGEXPS'.
  
  See Also: ATTRIBUTE FLAG, REGEXP, $-command, ^-listens



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



wildmatch()
  Function: wildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
 
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the number of the first word that matches.  If no words match then 0 is
  returned.  The case of the characters being matched is not significant.
 
  The words in the string  may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' 
  matches any one character, while '*' matches any number of characters, 
  including none.  So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', 
  but 's*x' would match any of them.  <delim> may be used specified to 
  specify a delimiter other than a space.
  Examples:
    > say wildmatch(This is a test, test)
    You say "4"
    > say wildmatch(This is a test, is)
    You say "2"
    > say wildmatch(This *is* a test, whiss)
    You say "2"
    > say wildmatch(This is a test *, *not*)
    You say "5"
    > say wildmatch(This is a test, is a)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: member(), strmatch(), subnetmatch(), numwildmatch(), 
            totwildmatch(), match()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WIPE()
  Function: wipe(<obj>[/wildattr] [[,<regexp>] [,<ownerkey>] [,<preserve>]])
            wipe(<owner>/<obj>[/wildattr], [,<regexp>], 1, [,<preserve>])
  
  The wipe() function will remove all matching attributes specified by
  a wildcard, or, if no attribute is specified, remove all attributes of
  the specified object.  This function works like @wipe and follows all
  permissions and restrictions of the matching command.
  
  If <regexp> is specified as '1', then <wildattr> is evaluated as a
  regular expresion instead of the default expresion.
  
  If <ownerkey> is specified as '1', then, as the second syntax example above,
  it takes the additional <owner> argument as the owner to compare against.
  
  If <preserve> is specified as '1', it takes the reverse of the wipe and
  keeps the specified wildcard pattern and wipes everything else.
   
  Check @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  Anything using this side-effect must have the SIDEFX flag set.
  
  Examples:
    > say wipe(Corum/#123/*foo,,1)   (this wipes attribs owned by Corum only)
    You say "Wipe: 1 attributes wiped."
    > say wipe(#123/*foo*)
    You say "Wipe: 8 attributes wiped."
    > say wipe(#123/^.*ab$,1)
    You say "Wipe: 2 attributes wiped."
    > say wipe(#123)
    You say "Wipe: 218 attributes wiped."
  
  See Also: @wipe, @set, &, set()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WIZARD ATTRIBUTES
  Topic: WIZARD ATTRIBUTES
  
  This is a backward compatible ability to set attributes that are
  wizard settable and seeable.  This is obsoleted now with the addition
  of the wizard command '@aflags'.
  
  Examples: 
    > &_foo me=Only a wiz can see or set this.
    Set.
    > @aflags _foo
    (Attribute 231028) Flags are: private [hidden wizard] 
  
  Wizard help: @aflags, _
  
  See Also: &, @set



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WIZARDS
  Topic: WIZARDS
  
  There are various levels of wizards.  From GUILDMASTER to IMMORTAL.
   
  Wizards are the people that help run the game and make sure that everything
  is working properly.  They have special powers to tweak reality in ways
  mortals can only dream of.  Be nice to them, they are going out of their
  way to help keep the game running smoothly.
 
  At RhostMUSH there is an additional class of administrators.
  There are currently the following bit levels:
  
    Immortal, Royalty, Councilor, Architect, Guildmaster, Wanderer, Guest
  
  Check news for a current list of all Royalty and Admins.
  
  See Also: IMMORTAL, ROYALTY, COUNCILOR, ARCHITECT, GUILDMASTER
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



wordpos()
  Function: wordpos(<string>, <charpos>[, <delim>])
 
  Returns the number of the word within <string> where the character position
  <charpos> falls.  Spaces between words are treated as belonging to the word
  that follows them.  If <charpos> is not within the string, the value #-1 is
  returned.  Both words and characters are numbered starting at 1.
 
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
 
  Example:
    > say wordpos(This is a test, 4)
    You say "1"
    > say wordpos(This is a test, 5)
    You say "2"
    > say wordpos(This is a test, 6)
    You say "2"
    > say wordpos(This is a test, 20)
    You say "#-1"
  
  See Also: words(), strlen()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WORDS()
  Function:  words(<string>[, <delim>])
            mwords(<string>[, <multi-character-delim>])
   
  Returns the number of words in <string>.  <delim> may be used to specify
  a delimiter other than a space.  mwords() works just like words, except
  that ignores ansi and allows a multi-character delimiter.
   
  Example:
    > say words(This is a test)
    You say "4"
    say words(Would you like coffee or perhaps tea?)
    > You say "7"
    say words(This:is:a:colon:separated:list,:)
    > You say "6"
  
  See Also: wordpos(), strlen(), extract(), extractword()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



worn
  Command: worn
  If alternate inventories are enabled, this command will show you what is
  currently being 'worn' by yourself.  Things 'worn' are identified by having
  a special wizard @toggle 'WORN' set on them.
  
  See Also: inventory, wielded
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WRAP()
  Function: wrap(<txt>,<width>[,<jst>,[<ltxt>[,<rtxt>[,<hanging>][,<jstcut>]]])
   
  This function word wraps the text to fit into a column of the
  specified width.  Words are separated by spaces. If a word in the text
  is longer than a single line, it is simply broken at the end of the
  line. Tabs are expanded to 8 spaces, and %r's are treated as a force
  to the next line, overriding the logic of the word wrapping. 
  
  <jst> may be any of the following.  You can just use the first character.
     left      - all text is wrapped to the left margen
     right     - all text is wrapped to the right margen
     center    - all text is wrapped to the center
     justified - all text is 'stretched' from the left to right margen.
                 This has a newspaper like effect.
     ignore    - all text is wrapped but padding is ignored.  This is useful
                 to pass into other functions such as printf().
   
  The <ltxt> and <rtxt> specify text to insert as borders on either the left
  side or right side of each line. They default to nothing.
    
  The <hanging> argument specifies an optional number of spaces to insert on
  the left margin for any line that is not the first line. This is commonly
  called a hanging indent in word processing.
  
{ 'help wrap2' for more }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WRAP2
  Function: wrap(<txt>,<width>[,<jst>,[<ltxt>[,<rtxt>[,<hanging>][,<jstcut>]]])
  
  The <jstcut> is used for when the string sent to wrap() isn't as large
  as the width you specified.  If this condition is true, and you use
  'justified' as the justification method, then it will assume a left
  justification for that line.  This is to avoid large spaces between
  strings for the very last line in a wrap().  
   
  Examples:
    > @emit wrap(Hi there. How are you?, 10, right, |%b, %b|)
      |  Hi there. |
      |    How are |
      |       you? |
    
    > @emit DESC: [wrap(get(me/desc), 10, left,,,6)]
      DESC: You see 
            before 
            you a
            stranger.
   
  
  The width can not be above 4000 characters.
  
  See Also: ljust(), rjust(), center(), columns(), wrapcolumns(), printf(),
            array(), template()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WRAPCOLUMNS()
  Function: wrapcolumns()  Syntax follows:
  wrapcolumns(<txt>,<wd>,<col>,<jus>,<crp>,<cut>,<lbd>,<mbd>,<rbd>,<dsp>,<ext>)
  
  This function has a huge number of uses, and all help will be given to show
  examples for what this function can do.  Unlike the columns() function, this
  one will wrap as many words as possible into a columns.  Like a newspaper.
  The arguments to this function are as follows.
    <txt>    - The text that you will be passing into columns.
    <wd>     - The maximum column size you desire.
    <col>    - The total number of columns you wish per line.
  * <jus>    - The justification of text in the columns (default left) 
               Arguments: (l)eft, (c)enter, (r)ight, or (j)ustified
  * <crp>    - Specifies if you want the columns cropped to the longest word or
               the max columns size whatever is smaller.
               Arguments: 1 to crop, 0 for no cropping (default).
  * <cut>    - Specifies that the word be cut off if over maximum columns size.
               Arguments: 1 to cut, 0 for no cutting (default).
  * <lbd>    - What text you want displayed as the left border of the line.
  * <mbd>    - What text you want as the separator between columns on the line.
  * <rbd>    - What text you want displayed as the right border of the line.
  * <dsp>    - What display type you want.  Down then over or over then down.
               Arguments: 1 for over then down, 0 for down then over (default)
  * <ext>    - Extension argument.  When toggled to '1' will extend a partial
               row to the maximum column width by padding it with spaces.
               This will use the column separator if the padding requires 
               multiple columns.
  
  Anything with an '*' are optional *only* if the first three args are used.
{ Type 'help wrapcolumns2' for examples }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WRAPCOLUMNS2
  Function: wrapcolumns()  (CONTINUED)
  wrapcolumns(<txt>,<wd>,<col>,<jus>,<crp>,<cut>,<lbd>,<mbd>,<rbd>,<dsp>,<ext>)
 
  There are various syntax possibilities for this command.  
  Examples:
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3)
      this is a wrapcolumns         
      test of   
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3,L,,,,,,1)
      this is a test of   wrapcolumn
      s         
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3,R)
       this is awrapcolumn         s
         test of
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3,R,0)
       this is awrapcolumn         s
         test of
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3,R,1)
       this is awrapcolumn         s
         test of
  
{ type 'help wrapcolumns3' for more examples }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WRAPCOLUMNS3
  Function: wrapcolumns()  (CONTINUED)
  wrapcolumns(<txt>,<wd>,<col>,<jus>,<crp>,<cut>,<lbd>,<mbd>,<rbd>,<dsp>,<ext>)
  
  Examples: (Continued)
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,3,3,R,0,0)
      thitespco
        s  tlum
       is of ns
        awra
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,3,3,R,0,1)
      thi  a of
       isteswra
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3,R,0,0,<*,|,*>,0)
      <* this is a|wrapcolumn|         s*>
      <*   test of*>
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3,R,0,0,<*,|,*>,1)
      <* this is a|   test of|wrapcolumn*>
      <*         s*>
    > @emit wrapcolumns(this is a test of wrapcolumns,10,3,R,0,1,<*,|,*>,1)
      <* this is a|   test of|wrapcolumn*>
  
  See Also: columns(), wrap(), printf(), array(), template()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



WRITABLE()
  Function: writable(<player>, <target>/<attrib>)
  
  This function checks if <player> can set attribute <attrib> on target player
  <target>.  You must control <player> otherwise it returns a failure (0).
  
  If <player> or <target> does not exist, it will return a failure (0).
  
  If <attrib> is an invalid attribute, it will return '0'.
  
  If <attrib> exists on <target>, it will check permissions and return '1' if
  <player> can set the attribute, '0' if it can not.
  
  If <attrib> does not exist, it will check the hash table for matching 
  permissions and return a '1' if the attribute would be settable on
  the <target> by the <player>, or a '0' if would not.
  
  Example:
    > say writable(bob, fred/desc)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: set(), rset()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XCON()
  Function: xcon(<object>[/switch],<start>,<count> [,<switch>] [,<objid>])
  
  This function is similiar to lcon() except it returns a space-separated list
  of the contents of <object> starting at point <start> and returning <count>
  number of contents.  It takes a specific switch as an option:
      /PLAYER    -- lists all TYPE players in the contents.
      /OBJECT    -- lists all TYPE objects in the contents.
      /CONNECT   -- lists all connected players in the contents.
      /PUPPET    -- lists all flag type 'PUPPET' in the contents.
      /LISTEN    -- lists all listening things in the contents.
      /CMDLISTEN -- lists all listening/command things in the contents.
      /VISIBLE   -- lists only things visible (not-dark) as if looking.
  
  You may optionally specify the switch as the second argument, without 
  the '/' before it, to do the same thing.  This will cause any /switch
  you have in the first argument to assume it's part of the object name.
  
  You may optionally specify <objid> as '1' to have it list objid's instead
  of the default dbref#'s.
   
{ type 'help xcon2' for examples }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XCON2
  Function: xcon(<object>[/switch],<start>,<count>)  (continued)
  
  Example:
    > inv
    t1(#366)
    radio(#223p)
    The Wizard's Pointy Hat(#188S0)
    A red rose(#1234C)
    Spybot(#2672p)
    You have 1086 Gold Coins.
    > say lcon(me)
    You say "#366 #223 #188 #1234 #2672"
    > say xcon(me,2,2)
    You say "#223 #188"
    > say lcon(me/puppet)
    You say "#223 #2672"
    > say xcon(me/puppet,2,1)
    You say "#2672"
    > say xcon(me,2,1,puppet)   
    You say "#2672"
    > say xcon(me,2,1,puppet,1)   
    You say "#2672:8281828218"
  
  See Also: lexits(), lcon()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XDEC()
  Function: xdec(<number> [,<key>])
  
  DEC() and XDEC() may be reversed.  to check if they are, Please reference:  
                           @list options system  
  
  The xdec() function is used to decrement the number passed into it.
  Any number passed into it is automatically decremented by one.
  
  If <key> is 1, it does advanced increments.  It then will take the number
  at the end of the string and increment, or if the string is a hexidicimal
  code starting with '0x' or '0X' it will increment the hex number. 
  
  Example:
    > say xdec(5)
    You say "4"
    > say xdec(-5)
    You say "-6"
    > say xdec(test123,1)
    You say "test122"
    > say xdec(0xfa,1)
    You say "0xf9"
  
  See Also: xinc(), inc(), dec(), add(), sub()
  
  Note:  Check @list options for the line 'Mux Formatted Inc() and Dec()'. If
         this is enabled, the functionality of inc() and dec() are swapped
         with xinc() and xdec() for MUX/Tiny style support.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XGET()
  Function: xget(<object>,<attribute>)
   
  The xget function fetches the specified attribute from the named object.
  It can be used to get attributes from objects you own, public and visual
  attributes of objects near you, and public and visual attributes other
  than the description of players wherever they may be.  If the attribute is
  not present on <object>, its parent is searched for the attribute.
   
  Example:
    > read me
    > say xget(me,desc)
    You say "My Desc"
  
  See Also: get_eval(), u(), get()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XINC()
  Function: xinc(<number> [,<key>])
  
  INC() and XINC() may be reversed.  to check if they are, Please reference:  
                           @list options system  
  
  The xinc() function is used to increment the number passed into it.
  Any number passed into it is automatically incremented by one.
  
  If <key> is 1, it does advanced increments.  It then will take the number
  at the end of the string and increment, or if the string is a hexidicimal
  code starting with '0x' or '0X' it will increment the hex number. 
  
  Example:
    > say xinc(5)
    You say "6"
    > say xinc(-5)
    You say "-4"
    > say xinc(test123,1)
    You say "test124"
    > say xinc(0xfa,1)
    You say "0xfb"
  
  See Also: xdec(), inc(), dec(), add(), sub()
  
  Note:  Check @list options for the line 'Mux Formatted Inc() and Dec()'. If
         this is enabled, the functionality of inc() and dec() are swapped
         with xinc() and xdec() for MUX/Tiny style support.
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XNOR()
  Function: xnor(<boolean1>,<boolean2>[,<booleanN>]...)
  
  Takes two or more booleans, and returns true(1) if both values are
  true(1) or false(0) and returns false(0) if any one value is
  false(0) but the other(s) are true(1).
  
  Example: 
    > say [xnor(1,0)] @ [xnor(0,0)] @ [xnor(0,1)] @ [xnor(1,1)]
    You say "0 @ 1 @ 0 @ 1"
  
  See Also: BOOLEAN VALUES, and(), xor(), or(), nand(), nor()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XOR()
  Function: xor(<boolean1>,<boolean2>[,<booleanN>]...)
   
  Takes two or more booleans, and returns 1 if an odd number of them are
  equivalent to true(1).
    
  Example: 
    > say [xor(1,0)] @ [xor(0,0)] @ [xor(0,1)] @ [xor(1,1)]
    You say "1 @ 0 @ 1 @ 0"
  
  See Also: BOOLEAN VALUES, and(), nor(), or(), nand(), xnor()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XORCHR()
  Function: xorchr(<string>,<listofcharacters>)
  
  This function returns true(1) if only ONE of the characters in
  <listofcharacters> exists in <string>.  It will return false(0)
  under every other situation.
  
  Examples:
    > say xorchr(wizards,qim)
    You say "1"
    > say xorchr(wizards,qmp)
    You say "0"
    > say xorchr(wizards,izdw)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: andchr(), orchr(), notchr()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XTERMCOLOR
  Flag: XTERMCOLOR([t])
  
  This flag is only meaningful for players.  When set in conjunction with
  the ANSI and ANSICOLOR flags, this will allow 256 ansi color support using
  the XTERM color pallet to be sent to the player's terminal.
  
  You need all three flags:  ANSI, ANSICOLOR, and XTERMCOLOR to see extended.
  
  See Also: ANSI, ANSICOLOR, SUBSTITUTIONS, ANSI(), NOFLASH, COLORS()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XTERMCOLOR LIST
             256 Color suport list.  [ansi(fg-value/bg-value,string)]
  With %c subs, use the 2 digit HEX value.  The ansi() function can use either.
        %c0x## -- foreground color (i.e. %c0x03%cn) -- ansi(0x03/,string)
        %c0X## -- background color (i.e. %c0X03%cn) -- ansi(/3,string)
  
  000 [0x00] Black           021 [0x15] Blue1         042 [0x2A] SpringGreen2
  001 [0x01] Red             022 [0x16] DarkGreen     043 [0x2B] Cyan3 
  002 [0x02] Green           023 [0x17] DeepSkyBlue4  044 [0x2C] DarkTurquoise 
  003 [0x03] Yellow          024 [0x18] DeepSkyBlue4  045 [0x2D] Turquoise2 
  004 [0x04] Blue            025 [0x19] DeepSkyBlue4  046 [0x2E] Green1 
  005 [0x05] Magenta         026 [0x1A] DodgerBlue3   047 [0x2F] SpringGreen2 
  006 [0x06] Cyan            027 [0x1B] DodgerBlue2   048 [0x30] SpringGreen1 
  007 [0x07] White           028 [0x1C] Green4        049 [0x31] MedSpringGreen
  008 [0x08] HilightBlack    029 [0x1D] SpringGreen4  050 [0x32] Cyan2 
  009 [0x09] HilightRed      030 [0x1E] Turquoise4    051 [0x33] Cyan1 
  010 [0x0A] HilightGreen    031 [0x1F] DeepSkyBlue3  052 [0x34] DarkRed 
  011 [0x0B] HilightYellow   032 [0x20] DeepSkyBlue3  053 [0x35] DeepPink4 
  012 [0x0C] HilightBlue     033 [0x21] DodgerBlue1   054 [0x36] Purple4 
  013 [0x0D] HilightMagenta  034 [0x22] Green3        055 [0x37] Purple4 
  014 [0x0E] HilightCyan     035 [0x23] SpringGreen3  056 [0x38] Purple3 
  015 [0x0F] HilightWhite    036 [0x24] DarkCyan      057 [0x39] BlueViolet 
  016 [0x10] Grey0           037 [0x25] LightSeaGreen 058 [0x3A] Orange4 
  017 [0x11] NavyBlue        038 [0x26] DeepSkyBlue2  059 [0x3B] Grey37 
  018 [0x12] DarkBlue        039 [0x27] DeepSkyBlue1  060 [0x3C] MediumPurple4 
  019 [0x13] Blue3           040 [0x28] Green3        061 [0x3D] SlateBlue3 
  020 [0x14] Blue3           041 [0x29] SpringGreen3  062 [0x3E] SlateBlue3 
  
  {see 'help xtermcolor list2' for more} 



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XTERMCOLOR LIST2
                                 [continued]
             256 Color suport list.  [ansi(fg-value/bg-value,string)]
  With %c subs, use the 2 digit HEX value.  The ansi() function can use either.
  
  063 [0x3F] RoyalBlue1      084 [0x54] SeaGreen1     105 [0x69] LightSlateBlue
  064 [0x40] Chartreuse4     085 [0x55] SeaGreen1     106 [0x6A] Yellow4      
  065 [0x41] DarkSeaGreen4   086 [0x56] Aquamarine1   107 [0x6B] DrkOliveGreen3
  066 [0x42] PaleTurquoise4  087 [0x57] DrkSlateGray2 108 [0x6C] DarkSeaGreen  
  067 [0x43] SteelBlue       088 [0x58] DarkRed       109 [0x6D] LightSkyBlue3

  069 [0x45] CornflowerBlue  090 [0x5A] DarkMagenta   111 [0x6F] SkyBlue2      
  070 [0x46] Chartreuse3     091 [0x5B] DarkMagenta   112 [0x70] Chartreuse2   
  071 [0x47] DarkSeaGreen4   092 [0x5C] DarkViolet    113 [0x71] DrkOliveGreen3
  072 [0x48] CadetBlue       093 [0x5D] Purple        114 [0x72] PaleGreen3    
  073 [0x49] CadetBlue       094 [0x5E] Orange4       115 [0x73] DarkSeaGreen3 
  074 [0x4A] SkyBlue3        095 [0x5F] LightPink4    116 [0x74] DarkSlateGray3
  075 [0x4B] SteelBlue1      096 [0x60] Plum4         117 [0x75] SkyBlue1      
  076 [0x4C] Chartreuse3     097 [0x61] MediumPurple3 118 [0x76] Chartreuse1   
  077 [0x4D] PaleGreen3      098 [0x62] MediumPurple3 119 [0x77] LightGreen    
  078 [0x4E] SeaGreen3       099 [0x63] SlateBlue1    120 [0x78] LightGreen    
  079 [0x4F] Aquamarine3     100 [0x64] Yellow4       121 [0x79] PaleGreen1    
  080 [0x50] MediumTurquoise 101 [0x65] Wheat4        122 [0x7A] Aquamarine1   
  081 [0x51] SteelBlue1      102 [0x66] Grey53        123 [0x7B] DarkSlateGray1
  082 [0x52] Chartreuse2     103 [0x67] LghtSlateGrey 124 [0x7C] Red3         
  083 [0x53] SeaGreen2       104 [0x68] MediumPurple  125 [0x7D] DeepPink4     
  
  {see 'help xtermcolor list3' for more}
