  See Also: XTERMCOLOR, ANSI, ANSICOLOR, ANSI()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



XTERMCOLOR SYNTAX
  @emit the following code (append the lines)
  
  System colors:%r[iter(lnum(0,7),%c0X[printf($02s,pack(##,16))]%b%b,,)]
  %cn%r[iter(lnum(8,15),%c0X[printf($02s,pack(##,16))]%b%b,,)]%cn%r%r
  Color cube, 6x6x6:%r[iter(lnum(0,5),iter(lnum(0,5),iter(lnum(0,5),%c0X
  [printf($02s,pack(add(16,mul(itext(1),36),mul(itext(2),6),itext(0)),16))]
  %b%b,,)%cn%b,,),,%r)]%cn%r%rGrayscale ramp:%r[iter(lnum(232,255),%c0X
  [printf($02s,pack(##,16))]%b%b,,)]%cn
  
  This will return a 256 color map for you.
  
  See Also: XTERMCOLOR, ANSI, ANSICOLOR, ANSI()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZATOZZ
  Command: @za[/<switch>] <object>=<string>
           ...
           @zz[/<switch>] <object>=<string>
  
  This sets attributes ZA - ZZ (with @za - @zz) on the target object.
  This is in effect just like &ZA or &ZZ but is provided for older MUSH
  backward compatibility.
  
  Optional switches are /quiet to suppress output or /noisy to give 
  verbose output.
  
  See Also: &
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZEMIT()
  Function: zemit(<list of zones>, <text> [,<key>])
  
  The zemit() function returns 'text' to every room of every zone in
  the specified list.  If the target zone is not a zonemaster, but still
  is contained in a zone, then it will just return the text to that room.
  This function by default evaluates '##' for each zone in the list and
  evaluates separately for every zone member.
  
  This works similiarilly to @pemit/zone/list
  
  Check @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.  
  Anything using this side-effect must have the SIDEFX flag set.
  
  Following <key> values exist:
    1 - disable ## substitution.
    2 - evaluate only once for every zone in list (disables ## automatically)
  
  Examples:
    > @zone here=#0
    > say zemit(#0,blarg)
    blarg   (Note: blarg will have been sent to all rooms of the zonemaster!)
    You say ""
    > say zemit(here,blarg)
    blarg   (Note: blarg is just sent to this current room)
    You say ""
    > @zone/purge here
    > say zemit(here,blarg)
    Invalid zone.
    You say ""
  
  See Also: @pemit, @emit, emit()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZFUN()
  Function: zfun([<zone>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
   
  The zfun function (similiar to u()) evaluates an attribute, either from the 
  default zone of the object performing the function or from another zone you 
  control or pass the zonemaster lock on, passing in arguments and returning
  the result.
  
  When evaluating the fetched attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and
  not the 'calling' object, and 'me' refers to the object that supplied the
  attribute.  Check @list options to see if zfun and zfun2 functionality are
  switched.
   
  Examples:
    > @zone me=#2 (if #2 is a valid zonemaster that you can link to)
    > @va #2=Word is [extract(v(vb),add(%0,1),1)], arg2 is %1.
    > @vb me=This is a test of the zfun function.
    > say lzone(me)
    You say "#2"
    > say zfun(va,4,Testing 123)
    You say "Word is of, arg2 is Testing 123."
    > say zfun(va,7)
    You say "Word is function., arg2 is ."
    > say zfun(#2/va,6,Foobar)
    You say "Word is zfun, arg2 is Foobar."
  
  See Also: zfun2(), zfuneval(), zfundefault(), zfunldefault(), zfunlocal(),
            zemit(), @pemit
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZFUN2()
  Function: zfun2([<zone>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
  
  This is nearly exactly like the original zfun() function except it parses
  in an object-dependant way like the old mushes.  It works by evaluating
  the function(s) by the power of the owner of the item it's on, and not
  by the power of the enactor.  
  
  This command is also very handy to keep security.
  
  For examples or more information, look at zfun()
  
  See Also: zfun(), zfun2local(), zfun2ldefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



zfun2default()
  Function:  zfun2default([<zone>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
 
  Works like zfundefault() but uses the zfun2() function instead of zfun()
  
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <zone>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the zfun2() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
 
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say zfun2default(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say zfun2default(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
 
  See Also:  get(), get_eval(), zfun2(), zfundefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



zfun2ldefault()
  Function:  zfun2ldefault([<zone>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
 
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <zone>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the u2local() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
 
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.  Unlike zfun2default(), it doesn't clobber
  %q0-%q9 registers.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say zfun2ldefault(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say zfun2ldefault(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
 
  See Also: get(), get_eval(), zfun(), zfundefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZFUN2LOCAL()
  Function:  zfun2local([<zone>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The zfun2local() function is almost identical to zfun2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or another object that you control or has the same owner as you, passing
  in arguments and returning the result. When evaluating the fetched
  attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and not the 'calling' object;
  'me' refers to the object that supplied the attribute.
 
  However, unlike the zfun2() function, the global registers r(0) through r(9)
  (%q0 - %q9) are preserved in their initial state. This means that functions
  "below" the level of the zfun2() can reset global registers for temporary
  calculations, without needing to worry about "clobbering" the original
  values.
 
  This makes zfun2local() particularly useful for global or shared code which
  calls arbitrary zfun2() functions, where global register values need to be
  preserved from accidental user clobbering.
 
{ See "help zfun2local2" for examples. }
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZFUN2LOCAL2
  Example of zfun2local():
    > @zone #2=#0
    > &FRUIT #2=apples bananas oranges pears
    > &SUB-FUNCTION #2=[setq(0,v(FRUIT))][extract(%q0,match(%q0,%0),1)]
    > &TOP-FUNCTION #2=[setq(0,are delicious!)][zfun2local(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say zfun2(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas are delicious!"
 
  If SUB-FUNCTION had been called with zfun2() instead of zfun2local():
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are delicious!)][zfun2(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say zfun2(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas apples bananas oranges pears"
 
  In this second example, in SUB-FUNCTION, %q0 was set to "apples bananas
  oranges pears", so that when the zfun2() "returned" and TOP-FUNCTION 
  evaluated %q0, this is what was printed. In the first example, zfun2local() 
  reset the value of %q0 to its original "are delicious!"
 
  See Also:  ulocal(), u(), u2(), uldefault(), u2ldefault(), setq(), r()



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



zfundefault()
  Function:  zfundefault([<zone>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
   
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <zone>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the zfun() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
   
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.
   
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say zfundefault(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say zfundefault(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
   
  See Also: get(), get_eval(), zfun(), zfundefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZFUNEVAL()
  Function: zfuneval([<zone>/]<attr>/permission[,<arg>],...)
  
  The zfuneval function evaluates an attribute, either from the object 
  performing the function or from another zone you control, passing in 
  arguments and returning the result.  In this way it works just like 'zfun()',
  except you pass in a permission to specify what permission level you wish to
  use for evaluation.  It assumes the enactor (owner) of the function always 
  succeeds.  When evaluating the fetched attribute, %# refers to the original 
  enactor and not the 'calling' object, and 'me' refers to the object that 
  supplied the attribute.  For more detail on functionality, look at ZFUN().
 
  The available permission levels are CIT[IZEN], GUILD[MASTER], ARCH[ITECT],
  COUN[CILOR], ROY[ALTY], IMM[ORTAL], SUB[EVAL].  You must have the permissions
  of the given level in order to use it else it defaults to your permission 
  level.  The permission must be included for the function to work.
  
  The special permission SUB[EVAL] will work like subeval() in that it will
  only evaluate substitutions on the target and not evaluate functions.
  
  Examples:
    > @set me=royalty (let's assume you're a wizard)
    > @va #2=[num(*Miriar)] (the ghod player - #1) (#2 a zone you control)
    > say zfuneval(va/royalty)
    You say "#1"
    > say zfuneval(va/citizen)
    You say "#-1"
  
  See Also: zfun(), zfun2(), objeval(), zfunlocal(), zfun2local(), sandbox(),
            subeval()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



zfunldefault()
  Function:  zfunldefault([<zone>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
 
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <zone>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the zfunlocal() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
 
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.  Unlike zfundefault(), it doesn't clobber 
  %q0-%q9 registers.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say zfunldefault(Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
    > &TEST me
    > say zfunldefault(me/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "-- BOOM --"
 
  See Also: get(), get_eval(), u(), default(), edefault()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZFUNLOCAL()
  Function:  zfunlocal([<zone>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
   
  The zfunlocal() function is almost identical to zfun() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or another object that you control or has the same owner as you, passing
  in arguments and returning the result. When evaluating the fetched
  attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and not the 'calling' object;
  'me' refers to the object that supplied the attribute.
   
  However, unlike the zfun() function, the global registers r(0) through r(9)
  (%q0 - %q9) are preserved in their initial state. This means that functions
  "below" the level of the zfun() can reset global registers for temporary
  calculations, without needing to worry about "clobbering" the original
  values.
   
  This makes zfunlocal() particularly useful for global or shared code which
  calls arbitrary zfun() functions, where global register values need to be
  preserved from accidental user clobbering.
   
{ See "help zfunlocal2" for examples. }
 


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZFUNLOCAL2
  Example of zfunlocal():
    > @zone #2=#0
    > &FRUIT me=apples bananas oranges pears
    > &SUB-FUNCTION #2=[setq(0,v(FRUIT))][extract(%q0,match(%q0,%0),1)]
    > &TOP-FUNCTION #2=[setq(0,are delicious!)][zfunlocal(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say zfun(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas are delicious!"
   
  If SUB-FUNCTION had been called with zfun() instead of zfunlocal():
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are delicious!)][zfun(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say zfun(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas apples bananas oranges pears"
   
  In this second example, in SUB-FUNCTION, %q0 was set to "apples bananas
  oranges pears", so that when the zfun() "returned" and TOP-FUNCTION evaluated
  %q0, this is what was printed. In the first example, zfunlocal() reset the
  value of %q0 to its original "are delicious!"
   
  See Also:  zfunlocal2(), zfun(), zfun2(), zfunldefault(), zfun2ldefault(), 
             setq(), r()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



zone functions
  Function Lists: Zone Functions.
    
  inzone()       - Returns the room in the specified zone master.
  zfun()         - Like u(), but from the perspective of a zone object.
  zfun2()        - Like u2(), but from the perspective of a zone object.
  zfundefault()  - Like udefault(), but from the perspective of a zone object. 
  zfun2default() - Like udefault2(), but from the perspective of a zone object.
  zfuneval()     - Evaluates code from the perspective of a zone object.
  zfunldefault() - Like uldefault(), but from the perspective of a zone object.
  zfunldefault2()- Like udefault2(), but from the perspective of a zone object.
  zfunlocal()    - Like ulocal(), but from the perspective of a zone object.
  zfun2local()   - Like u2local(), but from the perspective of a zone object.
  zwho()         - Returns the players in a specified zone master.
  zonecmd()      - Adds/Deletes/Purges zones from targets.
  lzone()        - Lists targets of a zone or zones of a target.



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONE_AUTOADD TOGGLE
  Toggle: ZONE_AUTOADD
  
  When this toggle is set on the target, whenever that target creates
  anything new (via @dig, @open, etc), that target will inherit the
  FIRST zone that the target belongs to.  If the target has no zones
  or if this toggle is not set, the zone addition is ignored.  If the
  target is also toggled ZONE_AUTOADDALL, that toggle will take
  presidence.
  
  See Also: ZONE_AUTOADDALL
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONE_AUTOADDALL TOGGLE
  Toggle: ZONE_AUTOADDALL
  
  When this toggle is set on the target, whenever that target creates
  anything new (via @dig, @open, etc), that target will inherit ALL
  of the zones that the target belongs to.  If the target has no zones
  or if this toggle is not set, the zone addition is ignored.  This
  toggle has presidence over ZONE_AUTOADD.
  
  See Also: ZONE_AUTOADD
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONECMD()
  Function: zonecmd(<command>, <target> [,<zone string>])
  
  Note: This function requires the SIDEFX flag.
  
  The <zone string> in most cases will be the zone or target.  The exception 
  is the replace command which requires the string of <oldzone>/<newzone>.
  
  This function duplicates the features of @zone, minus the list 
  ability which can be found with lzone().  The following <commands>
  are currently available with this function:
    list    -- (shorthand with 'l') List zones on target zonemaster or all the 
               zonemasters on the target zone.  You may specify <boolean> to
               '1' (true) if you wish to show the list as objid's.
               Syntax: zonecmd(list, target [,<boolean>])
  
    add     -- (shorthand with 'a') allows you to add a <target> to the the 
               specified <zone>.  It does sanity check and like @zone you can 
               not add a zonemaster to another zone.  
               Syntax: zonecmd(add, target, zone)
   
    delete  -- (shorthand with 'd') allows you to delete the <target>
               from the zone.  You can swap <target> and <zone> for
               the same effect.
               Syntax: zonecmd(del, target, zone)
                       zonecmd(del, zone, target)
  
    replace -- (shorthand with 'r') allows you to replace the zonemaster from
               the target with the new zonemaster.
               Syntax: zonecmd(replace, target, oldzone/newzone)
  
    purge   -- (shorthand with 'p') allows you to purge all zones
               from <target>.  If a non-zonemaster is specified, it
               will purge all zones from the target.  If a zonemaster
               is specified, it will purge all members from that zone.
               Syntax: zonecmd(purge, target)
 
{ see 'help zonecmd2' for examples}
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONECMD2 
 (CONTINUED)
  Function: zonecmd(<command>, <target> [,<zone string>])
  
  A successful execution of this function returns no output, otherwise
  any error will start with #-1 for coding checks.
  
  You can belong to multiple zones at the same time.
    
  Examples:
    > @set #123=zonemaster
    Set.
    > @set #789=zonemaster
    Set.
    > @set #12345=zonemaster
    Set.
    > say zonecmd(add,me,#789)
    You say ""
    > say zonecmd(add,me,#12345)
    You say ""
    > say zonecmd(list,me)
    You say "#789 #12345"
    > say zonecmd(replace,me,#789/#123)
    You say ""
    > say zonecmd(list,me)
    You say "#123 #12345"
    > say zonecmd(add,me,#123)
    You say "#-1 ALREADY IN ZONE"
    > say zonecmd(del,me,#123)
    You say ""
    > say zonecmd(del,me,#123)
    You say "#-1 NOT IN ZONE"
    > say zonecmd(list,me)
    You say "#12345"
  
  See Also: @zone, ZONES, lzone(), inzone(), zwho()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONECMDCHK
  Toggle: ZONECMDCHK(k)
  
  This toggle, when set, will enable the target to search for $commands
  from a zone as if it were a parent.  This is only useful on commands
  and players.  This toggle is meaningless on rooms (as rooms are already
  searched).
  



[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONECONTENTS
  Flag: ZONECONTENTS([z])
  
  When this flag is set on a room which is also set ZONEMASTER, then that
  zonemaster's contents will be searched for any matching $command.
  This will, in effect, work like a mini-master room.
  
  The ZONEMASTER flag must be set before this flag can be set.
  
  See Also: ZONES, IC, COMBAT, ZONEMASTER, @zone
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONEMASTER
  Flag: ZONEMASTER([Z])
 
  When this flag is set on a room or object it specifies it as the control
  object for a zone. A zone is defined in two ways. First a zone is a 
  group of ROOMS that create a physical geographic area (need not be 
  connected, but would be nice). These rooms are zoned to the zone master
  and whenever anyone enters a command that is not matched on an object 
  local to them, the zone master is searched for the command. If the command
  is found on the zone master then it is executed with the zone master as %!
  and the player/object that entered the command as %#.
 
  A zone is also defined as a group of rooms/objects/exits/players who
  are zoned to the zone master. These objects may be modified and controlled
  by anyone who passes the ZoneWizLock on the zonemaster.
  
  If the item is also set ZONECONTENTS, this flag can not be removed without
  the ZONECONTENTS flag being removed first.  Also, if there are existing 
  zones on the Zone Master, this flag can not be removed.
   
  See Also: ZONES, IC, COMBAT, ZONECONTENTS, @zone
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZONEPARENT 
  Flag: ZONEPARENT([y])
  
  This flag specifies if the ZMO is to 'distribute' or allow its attributes
  to be inherited to the things that belong to its zone.  Anything that
  you do not wish to inherit its attributes, if it is set ZONEPARENT, must
  be set NOZONEPARENT.  Alternately, individual attributes may be specified
  to not be inheritable if set NO_INHERIT.
  
  See Also: NOZONEPARENT, @set2
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



zones
  The RhostMUSH zone system works as follows:
  
  A zone is held together by a Zone Master. A Zone Master is an object or
  room that has it's ZONEMASTER flag set. Once the flag is set, you may
  do several things. To start with, you may decide you want others to
  be able to have their objects join your zone. To do this set up a 
  ZoneToLock on your ZONEMASTER. This lock defaults to false unlike most
  other locks which default to true if they are missing.
 
  You may also want select few people to have control over objects in your
  zone. These people will have wizard-like control within your zone.
  To allow others control and modification ability to objects in your
  zone you would set a ZoneWizLock on your zone master. This lock defaults
  to false if missing (allowing no-one control). Note that you as an owner
  of the zone master must still give yourself explicit zone wizard status
  by putting yourself in the lock.
  
  You may also set a ZONEMASTER, ZONECONTENTS.  This flag will enable
  searching the contents of the Zone Master for matching $commands.
  
  You may also set a ZONEMASTER, ZONEPARENT.  This allows the zonemaster
  to allow its children to inherit attributes off the ZONEMASTER.  An object
  @toggled NOZONEPARENT will not inherit attributes from any zonemaster.
     
  { Type 'help zones2' for more info. }
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



zones2
  You may also want a VERY select few to be able to alter the zone master
  object itself. To do this set a TwinkLock on the zone master. This lock
  defaults to false. 
  
  Any commands that you place on your zone master object will be searched
  for by objects or players entering commands that are not matched on
  an object local to them if they are essentially in a room of your zone.
  Essentially in your zone means that they or any level of container that
  they are within is physically in a room that is zoned to your zone master.
  The parent of a zone master is not searched for commands when this
  command search occurs.
 
  Once you have set up your zone master, you (or anyone in your 
  zone master's ZoneToLock) may begin to add objects to your zone.
  To do this, use the @zone/add, @zone/del, and @zone/purge commands.
 
  See Also: @zone, @lock, lzone(), ZONEMASTER, ZONECONTENTS, ZONEPARENT
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
[NEXT]



ZWHO()
  Function: zwho(<zone> [,<type>] [,<objid>])
  Returns the players in the specified zonemaster.  If the target is not
  a zonemaster, or if the object is not a valid zone, it returns an
  empty list.  This is _not_ database intensive.  This is the default 
  <type> '0'.
  
  If you specify <type> '1' for the zwho(), it lists all players that reside
  inside every single location belonging to that zone.  Also not overly
  cost intensive.
  
  You may optionally specify the <objid> to '1' to show the listings as
  objid's instead of the default of dbref#'s.
   
  Example:
    > @set here=zonemaster
    > @zone here=#0   (a room)
    > say lcon(#0,player)
      You say "#1 #3 #5"
    > @zone here=#534 (a room)
    > @zone here=#987 (a player)
    > say lzone(here)
    You say "#0 #534 #987"
    > say lzone(here,,1)
    You say "#0:8294929292 #534:8285029852 #987:8572572727"
    > say zwho(here)
    You say "#987"
    > say zwho(here,1)
    You say "#1 #3 #5"
    > say zwho(here,1,1)
    You say "#1:8258757272 #3:8572757272 #5:8572572727"
  
  See Also: @zone, ZONES, lzone(), inzone(), zonecmd()
  


[PREV]
[TOP]
